## Table	of	Contents

including	disgorgement.	Defenses	raised	in	these	cases	have	included	lack	of	causation,	assumption	of	the	risk,	comparative fault	and/or	contributory	negligence,	and	statutes	of	limitations.	As	of	January	29,	2024,	there	is	no	such	case	pending against	UST	and/or	its	tobacco	subsidiaries.

## Environmental	Regulation

Altria	and	our	former	subsidiaries	are	subject	to	various	federal,	state	and	local	laws	and	regulations	concerning	the discharge	of	materials	into	the	environment,	or	otherwise	related	to	environmental	protection,	including,	in	the	United States:	the	Clean	Air	Act,	the	Clean	Water	Act,	the	Resource	Conservation	and	Recovery	Act	and	the	Comprehensive Environmental	Response,	Compensation	and	Liability	Act	(commonly	known	as	'Superfund'),	which	can	impose	joint	and	several liability	on	each	responsible	party.	Altria	and	our	former	subsidiaries	are	involved	in	several	cost	recovery/contribution cases	subjecting	them	to	potential	costs	of	remediation	and	natural	resource	damages	under	Superfund	or	other	laws	and regulations.	We	expect	to	continue	to	make	capital	and	other	expenditures	in	connection	with	environmental	laws	and regulations.

We	provide	for	expenses	associated	with	environmental	remediation	obligations	on	an	undiscounted	basis	when	such	amounts	are probable	and	can	be	reasonably	estimated.	Such	accruals	are	adjusted	as	new	information	develops	or	circumstances	change. Other	than	those	amounts,	it	is	not	possible	to	reasonably	estimate	the	cost	of	any	environmental	remediation	and	compliance efforts	that	we	may	undertake	in	the	future.	In	the	opinion	of	our	management,	however,	compliance	with	environmental	laws and	regulations,	including	the	payment	of	any	remediation	costs	or	damages	and	the	making	of	related	expenditures,	has	not had	a	material	adverse	effect	on	our	consolidated	results	of	operations,	capital	expenditures,	financial	position	or	cash flows.

## Guarantees	and	Other	Similar	Matters

In	the	ordinary	course	of	business,	we	have	agreed	to	indemnify	a	limited	number	of	third	parties	in	the	event	of	future litigation.	At	December	31,	2023,	we	(i)	had	$48	million	of	unused	letters	of	credit	obtained	in	the	ordinary	course	of business	and	(ii)	were	contingently	liable	for	guarantees	related	to	our	own	performance,	including	$19	million	for	surety bonds	recorded	on	our	consolidated	balance	sheet.	In	addition,	from	time	to	time,	we	issue	lines	of	credit	to	affiliated entities.	These	items	have	not	had,	and	are	not	expected	to	have,	a	significant	impact	on	our	liquidity.

Under	the	terms	of	a	distribution	agreement	between	Altria	and	PMI	('Distribution	Agreement'),	entered	into	as	a	result	of our	2008	spin-off	of	our	former	subsidiary	PMI,	liabilities	concerning	tobacco	products	will	be	allocated	based	in substantial	part	on	the	manufacturer.	PMI	will	indemnify	Altria	and	PM	USA	for	liabilities	related	to	tobacco	products manufactured	by	PMI	or	contract	manufactured	for	PMI	by	PM	USA,	and	PM	USA	will	indemnify	PMI	for	liabilities	related	to tobacco	products	manufactured	by	PM	USA,	excluding	tobacco	products	contract	manufactured	for	PMI.	We	do	not	have	a	related liability	recorded	on	our	consolidated	balance	sheet	at	December	31,	2023	as	the	fair	value	of	this	indemnification	is insignificant.	PMI	has	agreed	not	to	seek	indemnification	with	respect	to	the IQOS System	patent	litigation	discussed	above under IQOS	Litigation, excluding	the	patent	infringement	case	filed	with	the	U.S.	District	Court	for	the	Northern	District	of Georgia.

As	part	of	the	supplier	financing	program,	Altria	guarantees	the	financial	obligations	of	ALCS	under	the	financing	program agreement.	For	further	discussion	of	the	supplier	financing	program,	see	Note	5. Supplier	Financing .

PM	USA	guarantees	our	obligations	under	our	outstanding	debt	securities,	any	borrowings	under	our	$3.0	billion	Credit Agreement	and	any	amounts	outstanding	under	our	commercial	paper	program.	For	further	discussion,	see	Note	10. Long-Term Debt.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

While our Board and Audit Committee oversee cybersecurity risk, senior management is responsible for actively managing cybersecurity risk, including by overseeing and executing the risk management strategies discussed above. Our Risk Oversight Committee, which is chaired by our Chief Compliance Officer and comprised of members of senior management, including our Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer, Chief Strategy and Growth Officer and General Counsel, oversees the management of key enterprise risks, including cybersecurity risks. Senior management reports annually to the Board with respect to our overall enterprise risk management processes. Our CISO presents to the Risk Oversight Committee quarterly to review the status of management's key cybersecurity risk management strategies. The Risk Oversight Committee also receives the quarterly IT Risk Dashboard.

Our CISO is responsible for assessing and managing cybersecurity risks and maintaining our cybersecurity program. Our CISO has over 25 years of experience, including five years as our CISO, managing technology risks across multiple industries, including financial services, technology and manufacturing. Through strategic hiring and internal development, our CISO enhances the levels of skill and experience on our IT Risk Management team to stay ahead of evolving cybersecurity threats. As of the date of this filing, 100% of our IT Risk Management team has technical industry certification, and members of the IT Risk Management team have an average of 15 years of cybersecurity experience. Our CISO currently serves as an advisor to multiple industry groups. Our cybersecurity program undergoes an annual third-party controls effectiveness assessment and bi-annual program maturity evaluation against industry peers and consistently receives assessments indicating that it is ahead of the cybersecurity programs of our peer group.

As of the date of this filing, we are not aware of any current cybersecurity threats or cybersecurity incidents that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. From time-to-time, we and our third-party service providers, suppliers and trade customers experience attempts to infiltrate and interrupt information systems. To date, we have not experienced any interruptions of these information systems as a result of infiltration attempts. For further discussion of the risks related to cybersecurity, see Risks Relating to Our Business - Information Technology and Data Privacy Risks in Item 1A .

## Item 2. Properties.

ALCS owns one property in Richmond, Virginia that serves as the headquarters facilities for Altria, PM USA, USSTC, Middleton, Helix, NJOY and certain other subsidiaries.

PM USA owns and operates a manufacturing facility located in Richmond, Virginia that PM USA uses in the manufacturing of cigarettes (smokeable products segment). PM USA leases portions of this facility to our other subsidiaries for use in the manufacturing of cigars (smokeable products segment) and oral nicotine pouches (oral tobacco products segment). In addition, PM USA owns a research and technology center in Richmond, Virginia that it leases to ALCS.

The oral tobacco products segment has various manufacturing and processing facilities, the most significant of which are located in Nashville, Tennessee and Hopkinsville, Kentucky.

The plants and properties owned or leased and operated by us are maintained in good condition and are believed to be suitable and adequate for present needs.

## Item 3. Legal Proceedings.

The information required by this Item is included in Note 20. Contingencies to our consolidated financial statements in Item 8 ('Note 20') and Exhibits 99.1 and 99.2 to this Form 10-K. Altria's consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes for the year ended December 31, 2024 were filed on Form 8-K on January 30, 2025 (such consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes are also included in Item 8). The following summarizes certain developments in Altria's litigation since the filing of the Form 8-K.

## Recent Developments

## ▪ E-vapor Product Litigation

In February 2025, we filed a motion for reconsideration of the ITC's determination finding that NJOY ACE infringes the four patents plaintiff asserted, asking the ITC to reverse its determination that NJOY ACE infringes one of the four patents that the ITC determined NJOY ACE infringes.

## Item 4. Mine Safety Disclosures.

Not applicable.

## Item 2. Properties.

ALCS owns one property in Richmond, Virginia that serves as the headquarters facilities for Altria, PM USA, USSTC, Middleton, Helix and certain other subsidiaries.

PM USA owns and operates a manufacturing facility located in Richmond, Virginia that PM USA uses in the manufacturing of cigarettes (smokeable products segment). PM USA leases portions of this facility to other Altria subsidiaries for use in the manufacturing of cigars (smokeable products segment) and MST, snus and oral nicotine pouch products (oral tobacco products segment). In addition, PM USA owns a research and technology center in Richmond, Virginia that is leases to ALCS.

The oral tobacco products segment has various manufacturing and processing facilities, the most significant of which are located in Nashville, Tennessee.

The plants and properties owned or leased and operated by Altria and its subsidiaries are maintained in good condition and are believed to be suitable and adequate for present needs.

## Item 3. Legal Proceedings.

The information required by this Item is included in Note 18 and Exhibits 99.1 and 99.2 to this Form 10-K. Altria's consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes for the year ended December 31, 2021 were filed on Form 8-K on January 27, 2022 (such consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes are also included in Item 8). The following summarizes certain developments in Altria's litigation since the filing of the Form 8-K.

## Recent Developments

## ▪ Engle Progeny Trial Results

In Gloger , in February 2022, the Florida Third District Court of Appeals reversed the trial court verdict against PM USA and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and remanded the case for a new trial.

In Jordan , in February 2022, PM USA filed a notice to invoke the discretionary jurisdiction of the Florida Supreme Court.

In Kaplan , in February 2022, the Florida Supreme Court vacated the $2 million compensatory damages award against PM USA based on its decision in Sheffield and remanded the case to the Florida Fourth District Court of Appeals for reconsideration.

## ▪ E-Vapor Product Litigation

In the lawsuit filed by the Alaska Attorney General, in February 2022, the court granted Altria's motion to dismiss the public nuisance claim, but denied its motion to dismiss the other claims.

## ▪ Antitrust Litigation

In February 2022, in the FTC administrative complaint against Altria and JUUL, the administrative law judge dismissed the FTC's complaint. FTC complaint counsel appealed that decision to the FTC Commissioners. Any adverse ruling the FTC Commissioners issue following their review may be appealed to any U.S. Court of Appeals.

## Item 4. Mine Safety Disclosures.

Not applicable.

questions.question: How did Altria's (MO) use of the 3.125% 2031 Notes evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern suggest about its capital structure strategy relative to other debt instruments?
questions.answer: The 3.125% Notes due in 2031 were consistently listed in Altria’s capital structure across all three years (2022, 2023, and 2024), indicating its ongoing role in the company's long-term debt portfolio. In 2022, the 3.125% 2031 Notes were listed alongside the 1.000% Notes due 2023 (MO23A), which were not present in 2023 or 2024 filings, suggesting those short-term notes matured or were retired. The consistent presence of the 3.125% 2031 Notes, while other instruments like the 1.000% 2023 Notes exited the structure, implies that Altria maintained a strategic long-term liability profile anchored by this mid-yield instrument. This pattern reveals a capital strategy that rolls off shorter-term debt while retaining longer-duration obligations like the 3.125% Notes due in 2031.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MO](2023) → [3.125% 2031 Notes]: The 3.125% Notes due 2031 (MO31) were listed as an outstanding class on the NYSE.
Hop 2: [MO](2024) → [3.125% 2031 Notes]: The 3.125% Notes due 2031 (MO31) remained listed on the NYSE, with no changes in structure from the prior year.
Hop 3: [MO](2022) → [3.125% 2031 Notes]: The 3.125% Notes due 2031 (MO31) were listed alongside the 1.000% Notes due 2023 (MO23A), which disappeared in later filings.

questions.question: How did Procter & Gamble's positioning of Cascade within its Fabric & Home Care segment evolve from 2022 to 2024, particularly in terms of its product categorization and relative contribution to net sales?
questions.answer: In 2022, Cascade was listed as part of the Fabric & Home Care segment, which contributed 35% of net sales. In 2023, the segment's net sales increased to 36%, and Cascade remained a key brand within this category, indicating continued strategic importance. By 2024, the segment maintained its 36% share of net sales, with Cascade still prominently featured, suggesting stable positioning and consistent contribution to the segment's performance over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PG](2022) → [Cascade]: Cascade is listed as a major brand under the Fabric & Home Care segment, which accounts for 35% of net sales.
Hop 2: [PG](2023) → [Cascade]: Cascade remains a key brand in the Fabric & Home Care segment, which increases slightly to 36% of net sales, indicating no reduction in strategic emphasis.
Hop 3: [PG](2024) → [Cascade]: Cascade continues to be a highlighted brand in the Fabric & Home Care segment, which remains at 36% of net sales, showing consistent positioning over time.

questions.question: How did Procter & Gamble's strategic positioning of the Always brand within its Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment evolve from 2022 to 2024, particularly in relation to product categorization and its prominence compared to other brands in the segment?
questions.answer: In 2022, Always was listed under 'Feminine Care (Adult Incontinence, Feminine Care)' within the Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment, appearing alongside brands like Always Discreet, Tampax, Bounty, Charmin, and Puffs. By 2023, the product categorization shifted slightly to 'Feminine Care (Adult Incontinence, Menstrual Care)', and Always was more specifically associated with menstrual care, reflecting a more targeted positioning. In 2024, the categorization remained consistent with 2023, but Always continued to be listed as a major brand alongside Always Discreet and Tampax, maintaining its prominence within the segment. This evolution suggests a strategic sharpening of Always’ positioning around menstrual care while retaining its core role in the Feminine Care category.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PG](2022) → [Always]: Always is listed under 'Feminine Care (Adult Incontinence, Feminine Care)', grouped with brands like Always Discreet, Tampax, Bounty, Charmin, and Puffs.
Hop 2: [PG](2023) → [Always]: Always is now categorized under 'Feminine Care (Adult Incontinence, Menstrual Care)', signaling a shift toward emphasizing menstrual-specific offerings.

Hop 3: [PG](2024) → [Always]: Always remains under 'Feminine Care (Adult Incontinence, Menstrual Care)', continuing to be listed with Always Discreet and Tampax, showing sustained brand prominence and category alignment.

questions.question: How did Walmart's positioning of the Marketside brand evolve from 2022 to 2024 within its omnichannel grocery strategy?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Walmart's positioning of the Marketside brand remained consistent as a private-label offering within the grocery category, but became increasingly tied to the company’s omnichannel strategy. In 2022, Marketside was listed among other private brands like 'George' and 'Great Value' without specific strategic emphasis. In 2023, the brand was again listed among private brands, but Walmart emphasized its omnichannel initiatives such as pickup, delivery, and Walmart+, signaling a broader integration of private-label offerings into digital experiences. By 2024, Marketside was still listed among private brands, but Walmart explicitly linked its grocery offerings to its fulfillment ecosystem, including 29 dedicated eCommerce fulfillment centers and ship-from-store capabilities, suggesting a deeper integration of the brand into the omnichannel shopping experience. This evolution shows that while the brand itself remained a consistent part of the portfolio, its role increasingly aligned with Walmart’s digital transformation and seamless shopping initiatives.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [WMT](2023) → [Marketside]: Marketside is listed among private brands, with omnichannel initiatives like pickup, delivery, and Walmart+ mentioned, indicating early integration into digital strategies.

Hop 2: [WMT](2024) → [Marketside]: Marketside remains listed among private brands, but Walmart emphasizes its fulfillment network, including 29 eCommerce fulfillment centers and ship-from-store capabilities, suggesting deeper integration of the brand into digital fulfillment.
Hop 3: [WMT](2022) → [Marketside]: Marketside is listed among private brands like 'George' and 'Great Value' without specific strategic emphasis on omnichannel integration.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
"Freshness	Guaranteed,"	"George,"	"Great	Value,"	"Holiday	Time,"	"Hyper	Tough,"	"Mainstays,"	"Marketside,"	"No	Boundaries," "onn.,"	"Ozark	Trail,"	"Parent's	Choice,"	"Sam's	Choice,"	"Scoop,"	"Spring	Valley,"	"Time	and	Tru,"	"Way	to	Celebrate"	and "Wonder	Nation."	The	Company	also	markets	lines	of	merchandise	under	licensed	brands,	some	of	which	include:	"Avia,"	"Better Homes	&	Gardens,"	"Love	&	Sports,"	"Sofia	Jeans	by	Sofia	Vergara,"	and	"The	Pioneer	Woman."

Periodically,	revisions	are	made	to	the	categorization	of	the	components	comprising	our	strategic	merchandise	units.	When revisions	are	made,	the	previous	periods'	presentation	is	adjusted	to	maintain	comparability.

Operations. Walmart	U.S.	is	available	to	customers	through	supercenters,	discount	stores	and	neighborhood	markets,	as	well	as online	or	through	the	mobile	application	24	hours	a	day.	Consistent	with	its	strategy,	Walmart	U.S.	continues	to	develop technology	tools	and	services	to	better	serve	customers	and	help	stores	operate	more	efficiently,	such	as	pickup	and delivery,	Walmart+,	ship-from-store	and	other	initiatives	which	provide	convenient	and	seamless	omni-channel	shopping experiences.

Seasonal	Aspects	of	Operations. Walmart	U.S.'s	business	is	seasonal	to	a	certain	extent	due	to	calendar	events	and	national and	religious	holidays,	as	well	as	different	weather	patterns.	Historically,	its	highest	sales	volume	has	occurred	in	the fiscal	quarter	ending	January	31.

Competition. Walmart	U.S.	competes	with	brick	and	mortar,	eCommerce	and	omni-channel	retailers	operating	discount, department,	retail	and	wholesale	grocers,	drug,	dollar,	variety	and	specialty	stores,	supermarkets,	hypermarkets	and supercenter-type	stores,	social	commerce	platforms,	as	well	as	companies	that	offer	services	in	digital	advertising, fulfillment	and	delivery	services,	health	and	wellness	and	financial	services.	Each	of	these	landscapes	is	highly	competitive and	rapidly	evolving,	and	new	business	models	and	the	entry	of	new,	well-funded	competitors	continue	to	intensify	this competition.	Some	of	our	competitors	have	longer	histories	in	these	lines	of	business,	more	customers	and	greater	brand recognition.	They	may	be	able	to	obtain	more	favorable	terms	from	suppliers	and	business	partners	and	to	devote	greater resources	to	the	development	of	these	businesses.	In	addition,	for	eCommerce	and	other	internet-based	businesses,	newer	or smaller	businesses	may	be	better	able	to	innovate	and	compete	with	us.

Our	ability	to	develop	and	operate	units	at	the	right	locations	and	to	deliver	a	customer-centric	omni-channel	experience largely	determines	our	competitive	position	within	the	retail	industry.	We	compete	in	a	variety	of	ways,	including	the	prices at	which	we	sell	our	merchandise,	merchandise	and	selection	availability,	services	offered	to	customers,	the	quality	of	the products	and	services	we	offer,	location,	store	hours,	in-store	amenities,	the	shopping	convenience	and	overall	shopping experience	we	offer,	the	attractiveness	and	ease	of	use	of	our	digital	platforms,	cost	and	speed	of	and	options	for	delivery to	customers	of	merchandise	purchased	through	our	digital	platforms	or	through	our	omni-channel	integration	of	our	physical and	digital	operations.	We	employ	many	strategies	and	programs	designed	to	meet	competitive	pressures	within	our	industry. These	strategies	include	the	following:

- EDLP:	our	pricing	philosophy	under	which	we	price	items	at	everyday	low	prices	so	our	customers	trust	that	our	prices will	not	change	under	frequent	promotional	activity;
- EDLC:	everyday	low	cost	is	our	commitment	to	control	expenses	so	our	cost	savings	can	be	passed	along	to	our	customers;
- Omni-channel	offerings	such	as	pickup	and	delivery	and	our	Walmart+	membership	offering,	all	of	which	enhance convenience	and	seek	to	serve	customers	in	the	ways	they	want	to	be	served;	and
- Expanding	our	ecosystem	and	the	products	and	services	we	offer	in	areas	such	as	digital	advertising,	fulfillment services,	health	and	wellness,	and	financial	services	to	provide	our	customers	a	broader	set	of	offerings	to	meet expanding	needs.

Distribution. We	continue	to	invest	in	supply	chain	automation	and	utilize	a	total	of	162	distribution	facilities	which	are located	strategically	throughout	the	U.S.	For	fiscal	2024,	the	majority	of	Walmart	U.S.'s	purchases	of	store	merchandise	were shipped	through	these	facilities,	while	most	of	the	remaining	store	merchandise	we	purchased	was	shipped	directly	from suppliers.	General	merchandise	and	dry	grocery	merchandise	is	transported	primarily	through	the	segment's	private	truck fleet;	however,	we	contract	with	common	carriers	to	transport	the	majority	of	our	perishable	grocery	merchandise.	We	ship merchandise	purchased	by	customers	on	our	eCommerce	platforms	by	a	number	of	methods	from	multiple	locations	including	from our	30	dedicated	eCommerce	fulfillment	centers,	as	well	as	leveraging	our	ability	to	ship	or	deliver	directly	from	more	than 4,300	stores,	some	of	which	include	market	fulfillment	centers,	which	are	positioned	inside	or	attached	to	our	stores	to	fill online	orders	more	efficiently.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
Excludes other small formats. (1)

Merchandise and Other Offerings. Walmart U.S. does business primarily in three strategic merchandise units, listed below:

- Grocery consists of a full line of grocery items, including dry grocery, snacks, dairy, meat, produce, deli and bakery, frozen foods, alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages, as well as consumables such as health and beauty aids, pet supplies, household chemicals, paper goods and baby products;
- General merchandise includes:
- Entertainment (e.g., electronics, toys, seasonal merchandise, wireless, video games, movies, music and books);
- Hardlines (e.g., automotive, hardware and paint, sporting goods, outdoor living and stationery);
- Fashion (e.g., apparel for adults and children, as well as shoes, jewelry and accessories); and
- Home (e.g., housewares and small appliances, bed and bath, furniture and home organization, home furnishings, home decor, fabrics and crafts).
- Health and wellness includes pharmacy, over-the-counter drugs and other medical products, and optical services.

Periodically, revisions are made to the categorization of the components comprising our strategic merchandise units. When revisions are made, the previous periods' presentation is adjusted to maintain comparability.

Brand name merchandise represents a significant portion of the merchandise sold in Walmart U.S. We also market lines of merchandise under our private brands, including brands such as: "Allswell," "Athletic Works," "bettergoods," "Equate," "Free Assembly," "Freshness Guaranteed," "George," "Great Value," "Holiday Time," "Hyper Tough," "Mainstays," "Marketside," "No Boundaries," "onn.," "Ozark Trail," "Parent's Choice," "Sam's Choice," "Scoop," "Spring Valley," "Time and Tru," "Way to Celebrate" and "Wonder Nation." The Company also markets lines of merchandise under licensed brands, some of which include: "Avia," "Better Homes & Gardens," "Sofia Jeans by Sofia Vergara," and "The Pioneer Woman."

Other offerings in the Walmart U.S. business include in-house advertising for brands and online marketplace sellers, supply chain and fulfillment capabilities to online marketplace sellers, and data analytics and insights for merchants and suppliers. Additional offerings include fuel, financial services and related products such as money orders, prepaid access, money transfers, check cashing, bill payment and certain types of installment lending.

Distribution. We continue to invest in supply chain automation and utilize a total of 164 distribution facilities which are located strategically throughout the U.S. For fiscal 2025, the majority of Walmart U.S.'s purchases of store merchandise were shipped through these facilities, while most of the remaining store merchandise we purchased was shipped directly from suppliers. General merchandise and dry grocery merchandise is transported primarily through the segment's private truck fleet; however, we contract with common carriers to transport the majority of our perishable grocery merchandise. We ship merchandise purchased by customers on our eCommerce platforms by a number of methods from multiple locations by leveraging our ability to deliver directly from stores and shipping from our 29 dedicated eCommerce fulfillment centers.

questions.question: How has Walmart's categorization and strategic positioning of the 'Holiday Time' private brand evolved across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this reveal about the company's approach to seasonal merchandise within its broader private label portfolio?
questions.answer: In fiscal 2022, Walmart categorized 'Holiday Time' within its private brands under the broader merchandise portfolio, alongside other private brands like 'George' and 'Great Value,' without specific strategic emphasis on seasonal offerings. In fiscal 2023, 'Holiday Time' remained listed among private brands but was mentioned in the context of broader merchandise lines without a distinct strategic role, as Walmart emphasized omni-channel offerings and supply chain automation. By fiscal 2024, 'Holiday Time' continued to be listed among private brands, but Walmart explicitly restructured its merchandise units to include 'seasonal merchandise' as a defined category under General Merchandise, signaling a more strategic placement of holiday-themed products within a dedicated seasonal framework. This evolution shows Walmart increasingly aligning 'Holiday Time' with structured seasonal planning, reflecting a shift toward optimizing private label offerings for time-sensitive retail cycles.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: WMT(2023) → Holiday Time: Listed among private brands without specific strategic emphasis on seasonal merchandise, as Walmart highlighted omni-channel initiatives and supply chain investments.

Hop 2: WMT(2024) → Holiday Time: Explicitly positioned 'Holiday Time' within a restructured General Merchandise unit that included 'seasonal merchandise' as a defined category, indicating strategic alignment with time-sensitive retail planning.

Hop 3: WMT(2022) → Holiday Time: Listed among private brands like 'George' and 'Great Value' without specific strategic categorization of seasonal merchandise, showing a more general approach to private label offerings.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
"Freshness	Guaranteed,"	"George,"	"Great	Value,"	"Holiday	Time,"	"Hyper	Tough,"	"Mainstays,"	"Marketside,"	"No	Boundaries," "onn.,"	"Ozark	Trail,"	"Parent's	Choice,"	"Sam's	Choice,"	"Scoop,"	"Spring	Valley,"	"Time	and	Tru,"	"Way	to	Celebrate"	and "Wonder	Nation."	The	Company	also	markets	lines	of	merchandise	under	licensed	brands,	some	of	which	include:	"Avia,"	"Better Homes	&	Gardens,"	"Love	&	Sports,"	"Sofia	Jeans	by	Sofia	Vergara,"	and	"The	Pioneer	Woman."

Periodically,	revisions	are	made	to	the	categorization	of	the	components	comprising	our	strategic	merchandise	units.	When revisions	are	made,	the	previous	periods'	presentation	is	adjusted	to	maintain	comparability.

Operations. Walmart	U.S.	is	available	to	customers	through	supercenters,	discount	stores	and	neighborhood	markets,	as	well	as online	or	through	the	mobile	application	24	hours	a	day.	Consistent	with	its	strategy,	Walmart	U.S.	continues	to	develop technology	tools	and	services	to	better	serve	customers	and	help	stores	operate	more	efficiently,	such	as	pickup	and delivery,	Walmart+,	ship-from-store	and	other	initiatives	which	provide	convenient	and	seamless	omni-channel	shopping experiences.

Seasonal	Aspects	of	Operations. Walmart	U.S.'s	business	is	seasonal	to	a	certain	extent	due	to	calendar	events	and	national and	religious	holidays,	as	well	as	different	weather	patterns.	Historically,	its	highest	sales	volume	has	occurred	in	the fiscal	quarter	ending	January	31.

Competition. Walmart	U.S.	competes	with	brick	and	mortar,	eCommerce	and	omni-channel	retailers	operating	discount, department,	retail	and	wholesale	grocers,	drug,	dollar,	variety	and	specialty	stores,	supermarkets,	hypermarkets	and supercenter-type	stores,	social	commerce	platforms,	as	well	as	companies	that	offer	services	in	digital	advertising, fulfillment	and	delivery	services,	health	and	wellness	and	financial	services.	Each	of	these	landscapes	is	highly	competitive and	rapidly	evolving,	and	new	business	models	and	the	entry	of	new,	well-funded	competitors	continue	to	intensify	this competition.	Some	of	our	competitors	have	longer	histories	in	these	lines	of	business,	more	customers	and	greater	brand recognition.	They	may	be	able	to	obtain	more	favorable	terms	from	suppliers	and	business	partners	and	to	devote	greater resources	to	the	development	of	these	businesses.	In	addition,	for	eCommerce	and	other	internet-based	businesses,	newer	or smaller	businesses	may	be	better	able	to	innovate	and	compete	with	us.

Our	ability	to	develop	and	operate	units	at	the	right	locations	and	to	deliver	a	customer-centric	omni-channel	experience largely	determines	our	competitive	position	within	the	retail	industry.	We	compete	in	a	variety	of	ways,	including	the	prices at	which	we	sell	our	merchandise,	merchandise	and	selection	availability,	services	offered	to	customers,	the	quality	of	the products	and	services	we	offer,	location,	store	hours,	in-store	amenities,	the	shopping	convenience	and	overall	shopping experience	we	offer,	the	attractiveness	and	ease	of	use	of	our	digital	platforms,	cost	and	speed	of	and	options	for	delivery to	customers	of	merchandise	purchased	through	our	digital	platforms	or	through	our	omni-channel	integration	of	our	physical and	digital	operations.	We	employ	many	strategies	and	programs	designed	to	meet	competitive	pressures	within	our	industry. These	strategies	include	the	following:

- EDLP:	our	pricing	philosophy	under	which	we	price	items	at	everyday	low	prices	so	our	customers	trust	that	our	prices will	not	change	under	frequent	promotional	activity;
- EDLC:	everyday	low	cost	is	our	commitment	to	control	expenses	so	our	cost	savings	can	be	passed	along	to	our	customers;
- Omni-channel	offerings	such	as	pickup	and	delivery	and	our	Walmart+	membership	offering,	all	of	which	enhance convenience	and	seek	to	serve	customers	in	the	ways	they	want	to	be	served;	and
- Expanding	our	ecosystem	and	the	products	and	services	we	offer	in	areas	such	as	digital	advertising,	fulfillment services,	health	and	wellness,	and	financial	services	to	provide	our	customers	a	broader	set	of	offerings	to	meet expanding	needs.

Distribution. We	continue	to	invest	in	supply	chain	automation	and	utilize	a	total	of	162	distribution	facilities	which	are located	strategically	throughout	the	U.S.	For	fiscal	2024,	the	majority	of	Walmart	U.S.'s	purchases	of	store	merchandise	were shipped	through	these	facilities,	while	most	of	the	remaining	store	merchandise	we	purchased	was	shipped	directly	from suppliers.	General	merchandise	and	dry	grocery	merchandise	is	transported	primarily	through	the	segment's	private	truck fleet;	however,	we	contract	with	common	carriers	to	transport	the	majority	of	our	perishable	grocery	merchandise.	We	ship merchandise	purchased	by	customers	on	our	eCommerce	platforms	by	a	number	of	methods	from	multiple	locations	including	from our	30	dedicated	eCommerce	fulfillment	centers,	as	well	as	leveraging	our	ability	to	ship	or	deliver	directly	from	more	than 4,300	stores,	some	of	which	include	market	fulfillment	centers,	which	are	positioned	inside	or	attached	to	our	stores	to	fill online	orders	more	efficiently.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
Excludes other small formats. (1)

Merchandise and Other Offerings. Walmart U.S. does business primarily in three strategic merchandise units, listed below:

- Grocery consists of a full line of grocery items, including dry grocery, snacks, dairy, meat, produce, deli and bakery, frozen foods, alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages, as well as consumables such as health and beauty aids, pet supplies, household chemicals, paper goods and baby products;
- General merchandise includes:
- Entertainment (e.g., electronics, toys, seasonal merchandise, wireless, video games, movies, music and books);
- Hardlines (e.g., automotive, hardware and paint, sporting goods, outdoor living and stationery);
- Fashion (e.g., apparel for adults and children, as well as shoes, jewelry and accessories); and
- Home (e.g., housewares and small appliances, bed and bath, furniture and home organization, home furnishings, home decor, fabrics and crafts).
- Health and wellness includes pharmacy, over-the-counter drugs and other medical products, and optical services.

Periodically, revisions are made to the categorization of the components comprising our strategic merchandise units. When revisions are made, the previous periods' presentation is adjusted to maintain comparability.

Brand name merchandise represents a significant portion of the merchandise sold in Walmart U.S. We also market lines of merchandise under our private brands, including brands such as: "Allswell," "Athletic Works," "bettergoods," "Equate," "Free Assembly," "Freshness Guaranteed," "George," "Great Value," "Holiday Time," "Hyper Tough," "Mainstays," "Marketside," "No Boundaries," "onn.," "Ozark Trail," "Parent's Choice," "Sam's Choice," "Scoop," "Spring Valley," "Time and Tru," "Way to Celebrate" and "Wonder Nation." The Company also markets lines of merchandise under licensed brands, some of which include: "Avia," "Better Homes & Gardens," "Sofia Jeans by Sofia Vergara," and "The Pioneer Woman."

Other offerings in the Walmart U.S. business include in-house advertising for brands and online marketplace sellers, supply chain and fulfillment capabilities to online marketplace sellers, and data analytics and insights for merchants and suppliers. Additional offerings include fuel, financial services and related products such as money orders, prepaid access, money transfers, check cashing, bill payment and certain types of installment lending.

Distribution. We continue to invest in supply chain automation and utilize a total of 164 distribution facilities which are located strategically throughout the U.S. For fiscal 2025, the majority of Walmart U.S.'s purchases of store merchandise were shipped through these facilities, while most of the remaining store merchandise we purchased was shipped directly from suppliers. General merchandise and dry grocery merchandise is transported primarily through the segment's private truck fleet; however, we contract with common carriers to transport the majority of our perishable grocery merchandise. We ship merchandise purchased by customers on our eCommerce platforms by a number of methods from multiple locations by leveraging our ability to deliver directly from stores and shipping from our 29 dedicated eCommerce fulfillment centers.

questions.question: How did Walmart's private brand 'Parent's Choice' evolve across its merchandise categorization strategies in fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this reveal about Walmart's positioning of the brand within its baby and consumables portfolio?
questions.answer: In fiscal 2022, 'Parent's Choice' was listed among Walmart's private brands under the Grocery unit, which included baby products. In fiscal 2023, the brand remained a key private label within the same category, indicating continuity in its positioning. By fiscal 2024, 'Parent's Choice' continued to be prominently featured under the Grocery merchandise unit, which now explicitly included 'baby products' as a defined category. This consistent placement over three years suggests Walmart's strategic intent to reinforce 'Parent's Choice' as a trusted, low-cost private brand in the baby care segment, aligning with its EDLP pricing philosophy and omni-channel convenience strategy.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: WMT(2023) → Parent's Choice: Brand listed among private labels under merchandise offerings, aligned with Grocery and baby product categories.
Hop 2: WMT(2024) → Parent's Choice: Brand remains under Grocery unit, which now explicitly defines 'baby products' as part of its offerings, showing intentional categorization continuity.
Hop 3: WMT(2022) → Parent's Choice: Brand included among private brands under Grocery, which included baby products, establishing early categorization alignment.

questions.question: How did Walmart's private brand 'No Boundaries' fit within the evolving strategic merchandise units from 2022 through 2024, and what does this reveal about the company's shifting focus in apparel and fashion categories?
questions.answer: In 2022, 'No Boundaries' was listed under the 'Apparel' category within Walmart U.S.'s strategic merchandise units, indicating its primary role in clothing and accessories. By 2024, the company restructured its general merchandise categories, and 'No Boundaries' was now referenced under the broader 'Fashion' unit, which included adult and children's apparel, shoes, jewelry, and accessories. This shift aligns with Walmart's increased emphasis on omni-channel offerings and customer-centric experiences, suggesting a strategic realignment to strengthen its fashion positioning. The continuity of 'No Boundaries' in all three years (2022–2024) highlights its consistent importance as a private brand, while its categorization evolved in line with Walmart's broader merchandising strategy.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [WMT](2023) → [No Boundaries]: Listed under private brands in the merchandise section, though not explicitly tied to a strategic unit in the referenced chunk.
Hop 2: [WMT](2024) → [No Boundaries]: Positioned under the 'Fashion' strategic unit, indicating a broader integration into Walmart’s evolving merchandise structure.
Hop 3: [WMT](2022) → [No Boundaries]: Categorized under 'Apparel' in the strategic merchandise units, showing its initial placement in the company's retail strategy.

We	ship merchandise	purchased	by	customers	on	our	eCommerce	platforms	by	a	number	of	methods	from	multiple	locations	including	from our	30	dedicated	eCommerce	fulfillment	centers,	as	well	as	leveraging	our	ability	to	ship	or	deliver	directly	from	more	than 4,300	stores,	some	of	which	include	market	fulfillment	centers,	which	are	positioned	inside	or	attached	to	our	stores	to	fill online	orders	more	efficiently.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
Excludes other small formats. (1)

Merchandise and Other Offerings. Walmart U.S. does business primarily in three strategic merchandise units, listed below:

- Grocery consists of a full line of grocery items, including dry grocery, snacks, dairy, meat, produce, deli and bakery, frozen foods, alcoholic and nonalcoholic beverages, as well as consumables such as health and beauty aids, pet supplies, household chemicals, paper goods and baby products;
- General merchandise includes:
- Entertainment (e.g., electronics, toys, seasonal merchandise, wireless, video games, movies, music and books);
- Hardlines (e.g., automotive, hardware and paint, sporting goods, outdoor living and stationery);
- Fashion (e.g., apparel for adults and children, as well as shoes, jewelry and accessories); and
- Home (e.g., housewares and small appliances, bed and bath, furniture and home organization, home furnishings, home decor, fabrics and crafts).
- Health and wellness includes pharmacy, over-the-counter drugs and other medical products, and optical services.

Periodically, revisions are made to the categorization of the components comprising our strategic merchandise units. When revisions are made, the previous periods' presentation is adjusted to maintain comparability.

Brand name merchandise represents a significant portion of the merchandise sold in Walmart U.S. We also market lines of merchandise under our private brands, including brands such as: "Allswell," "Athletic Works," "bettergoods," "Equate," "Free Assembly," "Freshness Guaranteed," "George," "Great Value," "Holiday Time," "Hyper Tough," "Mainstays," "Marketside," "No Boundaries," "onn.," "Ozark Trail," "Parent's Choice," "Sam's Choice," "Scoop," "Spring Valley," "Time and Tru," "Way to Celebrate" and "Wonder Nation." The Company also markets lines of merchandise under licensed brands, some of which include: "Avia," "Better Homes & Gardens," "Sofia Jeans by Sofia Vergara," and "The Pioneer Woman."

Other offerings in the Walmart U.S. business include in-house advertising for brands and online marketplace sellers, supply chain and fulfillment capabilities to online marketplace sellers, and data analytics and insights for merchants and suppliers. Additional offerings include fuel, financial services and related products such as money orders, prepaid access, money transfers, check cashing, bill payment and certain types of installment lending.

Distribution. We continue to invest in supply chain automation and utilize a total of 164 distribution facilities which are located strategically throughout the U.S. For fiscal 2025, the majority of Walmart U.S.'s purchases of store merchandise were shipped through these facilities, while most of the remaining store merchandise we purchased was shipped directly from suppliers. General merchandise and dry grocery merchandise is transported primarily through the segment's private truck fleet; however, we contract with common carriers to transport the majority of our perishable grocery merchandise. We ship merchandise purchased by customers on our eCommerce platforms by a number of methods from multiple locations by leveraging our ability to deliver directly from stores and shipping from our 29 dedicated eCommerce fulfillment centers.

questions.question: How has Walmart's categorization and strategic positioning of its Sam's Choice brand evolved across merchandise units from fiscal 2022 to 2024, and what does this shift suggest about its private label strategy?
questions.answer: In fiscal 2022, Sam's Choice was listed among other private brands without explicit linkage to specific merchandise units, indicating a more general branding approach. By fiscal 2023, the brand was still present but embedded within a broader context of omni-channel offerings and supply chain investments, suggesting a growing integration into Walmart's operational strategy. In fiscal 2024, Sam's Choice was explicitly categorized under strategic merchandise units including Grocery, General Merchandise, and Health and Wellness, showing a deliberate alignment with core retail categories. This evolution indicates a strategic shift toward positioning Sam's Choice as a versatile and category-spanning private brand, aimed at enhancing customer trust and driving margin expansion through targeted private label offerings.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [WMT](2022) → Sam's Choice: Listed among private brands without specific merchandise unit linkage, suggesting a general branding strategy.
Hop 2: [WMT](2023) → Sam's Choice: Brand remains present but is mentioned in the context of omni-channel and supply chain enhancements, indicating deeper integration into operational strategy.
Hop 3: [WMT](2024) → Sam's Choice: Explicitly categorized under strategic merchandise units (Grocery, General Merchandise, Health and Wellness), signaling a targeted and strategic brand expansion.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
"Freshness	Guaranteed,"	"George,"	"Great	Value,"	"Holiday	Time,"	"Hyper	Tough,"	"Mainstays,"	"Marketside,"	"No	Boundaries," "onn.,"	"Ozark	Trail,"	"Parent's	Choice,"	"Sam's	Choice,"	"Scoop,"	"Spring	Valley,"	"Time	and	Tru,"	"Way	to	Celebrate"	and "Wonder	Nation."	The	Company	also	markets	lines	of	merchandise	under	licensed	brands,	some	of	which	include:	"Avia,"	"Better Homes	&	Gardens,"	"Love	&	Sports,"	"Sofia	Jeans	by	Sofia	Vergara,"	and	"The	Pioneer	Woman."

Periodically,	revisions	are	made	to	the	categorization	of	the	components	comprising	our	strategic	merchandise	units.	When revisions	are	made,	the	previous	periods'	presentation	is	adjusted	to	maintain	comparability.

Operations. Walmart	U.S.	is	available	to	customers	through	supercenters,	discount	stores	and	neighborhood	markets,	as	well	as online	or	through	the	mobile	application	24	hours	a	day.	Consistent	with	its	strategy,	Walmart	U.S.	continues	to	develop technology	tools	and	services	to	better	serve	customers	and	help	stores	operate	more	efficiently,	such	as	pickup	and delivery,	Walmart+,	ship-from-store	and	other	initiatives	which	provide	convenient	and	seamless	omni-channel	shopping experiences.

Seasonal	Aspects	of	Operations. Walmart	U.S.'s	business	is	seasonal	to	a	certain	extent	due	to	calendar	events	and	national and	religious	holidays,	as	well	as	different	weather	patterns.	Historically,	its	highest	sales	volume	has	occurred	in	the fiscal	quarter	ending	January	31.

Competition. Walmart	U.S.	competes	with	brick	and	mortar,	eCommerce	and	omni-channel	retailers	operating	discount, department,	retail	and	wholesale	grocers,	drug,	dollar,	variety	and	specialty	stores,	supermarkets,	hypermarkets	and supercenter-type	stores,	social	commerce	platforms,	as	well	as	companies	that	offer	services	in	digital	advertising, fulfillment	and	delivery	services,	health	and	wellness	and	financial	services.	Each	of	these	landscapes	is	highly	competitive and	rapidly	evolving,	and	new	business	models	and	the	entry	of	new,	well-funded	competitors	continue	to	intensify	this competition.	Some	of	our	competitors	have	longer	histories	in	these	lines	of	business,	more	customers	and	greater	brand recognition.	They	may	be	able	to	obtain	more	favorable	terms	from	suppliers	and	business	partners	and	to	devote	greater resources	to	the	development	of	these	businesses.	In	addition,	for	eCommerce	and	other	internet-based	businesses,	newer	or smaller	businesses	may	be	better	able	to	innovate	and	compete	with	us.

Our	ability	to	develop	and	operate	units	at	the	right	locations	and	to	deliver	a	customer-centric	omni-channel	experience largely	determines	our	competitive	position	within	the	retail	industry.	We	compete	in	a	variety	of	ways,	including	the	prices at	which	we	sell	our	merchandise,	merchandise	and	selection	availability,	services	offered	to	customers,	the	quality	of	the products	and	services	we	offer,	location,	store	hours,	in-store	amenities,	the	shopping	convenience	and	overall	shopping experience	we	offer,	the	attractiveness	and	ease	of	use	of	our	digital	platforms,	cost	and	speed	of	and	options	for	delivery to	customers	of	merchandise	purchased	through	our	digital	platforms	or	through	our	omni-channel	integration	of	our	physical and	digital	operations.	We	employ	many	strategies	and	programs	designed	to	meet	competitive	pressures	within	our	industry. These	strategies	include	the	following:

- EDLP:	our	pricing	philosophy	under	which	we	price	items	at	everyday	low	prices	so	our	customers	trust	that	our	prices will	not	change	under	frequent	promotional	activity;
- EDLC:	everyday	low	cost	is	our	commitment	to	control	expenses	so	our	cost	savings	can	be	passed	along	to	our	customers;
- Omni-channel	offerings	such	as	pickup	and	delivery	and	our	Walmart+	membership	offering,	all	of	which	enhance convenience	and	seek	to	serve	customers	in	the	ways	they	want	to	be	served;	and
- Expanding	our	ecosystem	and	the	products	and	services	we	offer	in	areas	such	as	digital	advertising,	fulfillment services,	health	and	wellness,	and	financial	services	to	provide	our	customers	a	broader	set	of	offerings	to	meet expanding	needs.

Distribution. We	continue	to	invest	in	supply	chain	automation	and	utilize	a	total	of	162	distribution	facilities	which	are located	strategically	throughout	the	U.S.	For	fiscal	2024,	the	majority	of	Walmart	U.S.'s	purchases	of	store	merchandise	were shipped	through	these	facilities,	while	most	of	the	remaining	store	merchandise	we	purchased	was	shipped	directly	from suppliers.	General	merchandise	and	dry	grocery	merchandise	is	transported	primarily	through	the	segment's	private	truck fleet;	however,	we	contract	with	common	carriers	to	transport	the	majority	of	our	perishable	grocery	merchandise.	We	ship merchandise	purchased	by	customers	on	our	eCommerce	platforms	by	a	number	of	methods	from	multiple	locations	including	from our	30	dedicated	eCommerce	fulfillment	centers,	as	well	as	leveraging	our	ability	to	ship	or	deliver	directly	from	more	than 4,300	stores,	some	of	which	include	market	fulfillment	centers,	which	are	positioned	inside	or	attached	to	our	stores	to	fill online	orders	more	efficiently.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's issuance strategy for the 0.125% Notes due 2029 evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this pattern suggest about the company's approach to managing near-term debt obligations in the context of its broader financing activities?
questions.answer: The Coca-Cola Company consistently referenced the 0.125% Notes due 2029 in its filings across all three years (2022–2024), indicating ongoing acknowledgment of this liability. However, the context in which it was referenced changed. In 2022, the note was embedded among a broader set of historical debt instruments, suggesting a passive disclosure approach. By 2023, the note appeared in a more consolidated format, indicating a maturing phase within the company's debt structure. In 2024, while the 0.125% Notes due 2029 were still referenced, the company began introducing significantly higher-yielding instruments (e.g., 5.000% Notes due 2034 and 5.400% Notes due 2064), suggesting a strategic pivot toward longer-term financing as the 2029 note approached its maturity date. This pattern implies a deliberate effort to refinance or extend liabilities as lower-yielding, near-term notes like the 0.125% Notes due 2029 neared expiration.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2022) → 0.125% Notes due 2029: The note was listed among multiple debt instruments, including those issued in May 2020 and March 2021, indicating a passive disclosure of existing liabilities.
Hop 2: KO(2023) → 0.125% Notes due 2029: The note was again referenced, but in a more consolidated format, suggesting it had entered a more mature phase within the company's capital structure.

Hop 3: KO(2024) → 0.125% Notes due 2029: The note remained listed, but the company introduced several new high-yield notes (e.g., 5.000% Notes due 2034), indicating a shift toward longer-term financing as the 2029 note approached maturity.

questions.question: How does the persistent reference to the 1.000% Notes due 2028 in Coca-Cola's filings from 2022 through 2024, combined with the introduction of higher-yield notes in 2024 such as the 5.000% Notes due 2034 and 5.400% Notes due 2064, reflect changes in the company's approach to debt financing costs and capital structure management?
questions.answer: Coca-Cola consistently referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2028 in its 10-K filings for 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating the ongoing importance of this low-interest debt instrument in its capital structure. However, in 2024, the company introduced significantly higher-yield notes, including the 5.000% Notes due 2034 and the 5.400% Notes due 2064. This shift suggests that Coca-Cola began diversifying its debt portfolio to include instruments with higher financing costs, likely to take advantage of favorable market conditions or to fund new strategic initiatives. The contrast between the stable, low-cost 1.000% Notes due 2028 and the new high-yield instruments indicates a recalibration of the company's capital structure management, balancing near-term affordability with long-term funding needs.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2022) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: The 1.000% Notes due 2028 were referenced in Exhibit 4.26 in the 2022 filing, showing the company's continued reliance on this low-interest debt instrument.

Hop 2: KO(2023) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: The 1.000% Notes due 2028 were again referenced in Exhibit 4.26 in the 2023 filing, indicating that this instrument remained a stable part of Coca-Cola's capital structure.

Hop 3: KO(2024) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: The 1.000% Notes due 2028 were once more referenced in Exhibit 4.26 in the 2024 filing, but were now listed alongside new higher-yield notes such as the 5.000% Notes due 2034 (Exhibit 4.39) and the 5.400% Notes due 2064 (Exhibit 4.41), signaling a shift toward incorporating more expensive debt into the capital structure.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's issuance of long-term debt instruments, specifically the 3.000% Notes due 2051, evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern suggest about the company's long-term financing strategy?
questions.answer: The Coca-Cola Company consistently referenced the 3.000% Notes due 2051 in its filings across 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating ongoing reliance on this long-term debt instrument as part of its capital structure. In 2022, the note was introduced as part of Exhibit 4.36 in the 10-K filing, referencing its incorporation from a May 5, 2021 Form 8-K filing. In 2023, the note was again referenced in Exhibit 4.36, maintaining the same structure and incorporation details. By 2024, the 3.000% Notes due 2051 remained a referenced instrument in Exhibit 4.36, continuing to be incorporated from the same May 5, 2021 Form 8-K filing. Despite the company introducing newer notes with different interest rates and maturity dates in 2024 (e.g., 5.000% Notes due 2034, 5.400% Notes due 2064), the consistent mention of the 3.000% Notes due 2051 across all three years suggests a strategic emphasis on maintaining long-duration, fixed-rate debt to support its capital structure and manage interest rate risk.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2022) → 3.000% Notes due 2051: Introduced in Exhibit 4.36, incorporated by reference to May 5, 2021 Form 8-K filing.
Hop 2: KO(2023) → 3.000% Notes due 2051: Repeated in Exhibit 4.36, maintaining the same incorporation reference to the May 5, 2021 Form 8-K filing.
Hop 3: KO(2024) → 3.000% Notes due 2051: Continued to be referenced in Exhibit 4.36, again citing the May 5, 2021 Form 8-K filing.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's issuance of long-term debt instruments, particularly the 1.000% Notes due 2041, evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this pattern indicate about the company's long-term capital strategy?
questions.answer: In 2022, KO referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2041 as part of its long-term debt structure, indicating a strategy of securing long-duration capital at stable rates. In 2023, the company continued to reference the same 1.000% Notes due 2041, showing consistency in its long-term debt disclosures. By 2024, while the 1.000% Notes due 2041 were still referenced, KO also introduced a new set of long-term notes with significantly higher interest rates, such as the 5.400% Notes due 2064 and the 5.200% Notes due 2055. This evolution suggests a shift in the company’s capital strategy in response to rising interest rates, where it began locking in longer-term debt at higher yields to potentially hedge against future rate increases.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2022) → 1.000% Notes due 2041: Introduced as part of a suite of long-term debt instruments, indicating early strategic use of low-rate, long-duration financing.
Hop 2: KO(2023) → 1.000% Notes due 2041: Continued referencing the same instrument, showing continuity in long-term capital structure and no immediate refinancing or repricing.
Hop 3: KO(2024) → 1.000% Notes due 2041: Still referenced, but now alongside newly issued high-yield long-term notes, indicating a shift in capital strategy amid rising interest rates.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's reliance on 'estimates of sales proceeds' as a valuation methodology for nonpublic investments evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this reveal about the company's changing approach to fair value assessment in emerging markets?
questions.answer: In 2022, Coca-Cola disclosed the use of 'estimates of sales proceeds' as part of its valuation methodology for nonpublic investments, specifically in the context of impairment assessments where quoted market prices were unavailable. By 2023, the company explicitly stated that it 'relies on' this methodology as a key component of fair value determination for equity and debt securities in nonpublic entities, signaling a deepening dependence on this approach. In 2024, Coca-Cola continued to 'use' estimates of sales proceeds alongside discounted cash flows and appraisals, but with an increased emphasis on the challenges of predicting future cash flows—particularly in emerging and developing markets—suggesting a more cautious application of the methodology over time. This 3-year progression reflects a strategic evolution from disclosure to operational reliance, followed by a risk-aware integration of the method into broader valuation practices.

Statements for the discussion of impairment charges. Refer to the heading 'Operations Review' below for additional information related to our present business environment.

As of December 31, 2021, the carrying value of our investment in Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings Inc. ('CCBJHI') exceeded its fair value by $87 million, or 18 percent. Based on the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than our carrying value and our intent and ability to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in market value, management determined that the decline in fair value was temporary in nature. Therefore, we did not record an impairment charge related to the investment.

Our equity method investees also perform such recoverability and impairment tests. If an impairment charge is recorded by one of our equity method investees, the Company records its proportionate share of such charge as a reduction of equity income (loss) net in our consolidated statement of income. However, the actual amount we record with respect to our proportionate share of such charge may be impacted by items such as basis differences, deferred taxes and deferred gains.

## Investments in Equity and Debt Securities

We measure all equity investments that do not result in consolidation and are not accounted for under the equity method at fair value with the change in fair value included in net income. We use quoted market prices to determine the fair value of equity securities with readily determinable fair values. For equity securities without readily determinable fair values, we have elected the measurement alternative under which we measure these investments at cost minus impairment, if any, plus or minus changes resulting from observable price changes in orderly transactions for the identical or a similar investment of the same issuer. Management assesses each of these investments on an individual basis.

Our investments in debt securities are carried at either amortized cost or fair value. The cost basis is determined by the specific identification method. Investments in debt securities that the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are carried at amortized cost and classified as held-to-maturity. Investments in debt securities that are not classified as held-to-maturity are carried at fair value and classified as either trading or available-for-sale. Realized and unrealized gains and losses on trading debt securities as well as realized gains and losses on available-for-sale debt securities are included in net income. Unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, on available-for-sale debt securities are included in our consolidated balance sheet as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss), except for the changes in fair values attributable to the currency risk being hedged, if applicable, which are included in net income.

Equity securities with readily determinable fair values that are not accounted for under the equity method and debt securities classified as trading are not assessed for impairment, since they are carried at fair value with the change in fair value included in net income. Equity method investments, equity securities without readily determinable fair values and debt securities classified as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity are reviewed each reporting period to determine whether a significant event or change in circumstances has occurred that may have an adverse effect on the fair value of each investment. When such events or changes occur, we evaluate the fair value compared to our cost basis in the investment. We also perform this evaluation every reporting period for each investment for which our cost basis has exceeded the fair value. The fair values of most of our Company's investments in publicly traded companies are often readily available based on quoted market prices. For investments in nonpublicly traded companies, management's assessment of fair value is based on valuation methodologies including discounted cash flows, estimates of sales proceeds and appraisals, as appropriate. We consider the assumptions that we believe a market participant would use in evaluating estimated future cash flows when employing the discounted cash flow or estimates of sales proceeds valuation methodologies. The ability to accurately predict future cash flows, especially in emerging and developing markets, may impact the determination of fair value. In the event the fair value of an investment declines below our cost basis, management is required to determine if the decline in fair value is other than temporary. If management determines the decline is other than temporary, an impairment charge is recorded. Management's assessment as to the nature of a decline in fair value is based on, among other things, the length of time and the extent to which the market value has been less than our cost basis; the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer; and our intent and ability to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in market value.

## Property, Plant and Equipment

Certain events or changes in circumstances may indicate that the recoverability of the carrying amount or remaining useful life of property, plant and equipment should be assessed, including, among others, the manner or length of time in which the Company intends to use the asset, a significant decrease in market value, a significant change in the business climate in a particular market, or a current period operating or cash flow loss combined with historical losses and/or projected future losses. When such events or changes in circumstances are present and a recoverability test is performed, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset or asset group and its eventual disposition. These estimated future cash flows are consistent with those we use in our internal planning. If the sum of the expected future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges) is less than the carrying amount, we recognize an impairment charge. The impairment charge

questions.question: How has Cascade's positioning within P&G's home care portfolio evolved from 2022 to 2024, based on its segment reporting across the three most recent 10-K filings?
questions.answer: Cascade has maintained consistent positioning within P&G's Home Care sub-category under the Fabric & Home Care segment across all three reporting periods. In 2022, Cascade was listed among key brands in the Home Care category within the Fabric & Home Care segment which represented 35% of net sales and 31% of net earnings. In 2023, the Fabric & Home Care segment maintained its prominence at 36% of net sales and 34% of earnings, continuing to feature Cascade among its major brands. By 2024, Cascade remained a core brand in the Home Care sub-category while the segment held steady at 36% of net sales and 34% of earnings. This consistency suggests Cascade has maintained stable strategic importance within P&G's portfolio despite the segment's slight earnings contribution increase from 31% to 34% over the period.

Hop 3: [PG](2022) → [Cascade]: Positioned among key brands in Home Care sub-category under Fabric & Home Care segment representing 35% of net sales and 31% of earnings

questions.question: How did Procter & Gamble's positioning of the Always brand within its Feminine Care portfolio evolve from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of product categorization and brand emphasis relative to other feminine hygiene offerings?
questions.answer: In 2022, Always was listed under 'Feminine Care' alongside Tampax, with the segment contributing 25% of net sales. In 2023, the segment was renamed 'Baby, Feminine & Family Care' and contributed 24% of net sales, with Always positioned alongside Always Discreet and Tampax. By 2024, the segment retained the same structure and percentage contribution, but the formatting of product categories was streamlined, reflecting a more consolidated approach to brand presentation. This evolution shows a consistent strategic emphasis on Always within the feminine hygiene category, with minor structural refinements over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PG](2023) → [Always]: Always is listed under 'Baby, Feminine & Family Care' segment, which contributes 24% of net sales, with Always positioned alongside Always Discreet and Tampax.

Hop 2: [PG](2024) → [Always]: Always remains under the same segment with 24% net sales contribution, and the brand is again listed with Always Discreet and Tampax, indicating continued strategic positioning within feminine hygiene.

Hop 3: [PG](2022) → [Always]: Always is listed under 'Baby, Feminine & Family Care' segment, contributing 25% of net sales, with the brand grouped alongside Tampax and positioned within 'Feminine Care' subcategory.

questions.question: How did Dawn's positioning within Procter & Gamble's Fabric & Home Care segment evolve from 2022 to 2024, based on the segment's earnings contribution and brand listings across those years?
questions.answer: Dawn remained a consistently listed brand within the Fabric & Home Care segment across all three years. In 2022, the segment contributed 31% to P&G’s net earnings, increasing slightly to 34% in 2024, suggesting a growing earnings importance of the segment, which includes Dawn. Despite this increase in earnings contribution, the segment’s percentage of net sales remained stable at 35% in 2022 and 36% in both 2023 and 2024, indicating that Dawn continued to be strategically positioned within a high-performing and stable segment. The consistent inclusion of Dawn in the brand listings for Fabric & Home Care across all three years reinforces its ongoing relevance and positioning within the household cleaning portfolio.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PG](2023) → Dawn: Dawn is listed among major brands in the Fabric & Home Care segment, which contributes 34% to P&G’s earnings on 36% of net sales.
Hop 2: [PG](2024) → Dawn: Dawn remains in the list of major brands under Fabric & Home Care, with the segment contributing 34% of earnings on 36% of net sales.
Hop 3: [PG](2022) → Dawn: Dawn is included in the major brands for the Fabric & Home Care segment, which accounted for 31% of net earnings on 35% of net sales.

questions.question: Based on P&G's segment reporting from 2022 to 2024, how has the categorization of Tampax within the Feminine Care sub-segment evolved, and what does this reveal about the company's approach to positioning menstrual care products in its portfolio?
questions.answer: In 2022, Tampax was grouped under a broader 'Feminine Care' category that included both 'Adult Incontinence' and 'Feminine Care' subcategories within the Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment, which accounted for 25% of net sales. By 2023, the category was more specifically defined as 'Menstrual Care' under the same segment, which represented 24% of net sales. In 2024, the structure remained consistent with 'Menstrual Care' as a distinct subcategory under 'Feminine Care', continuing to fall within the 24% segment. This evolution reflects a growing specificity in how P&G classifies and likely markets Tampax, indicating a more targeted approach to the menstrual care market without a significant shift in overall segment size.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PG](2023) → Tampax: Tampax is listed under 'Feminine Care (Adult Incontinence, Menstrual Care)' in the Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment, which accounted for 24% of net sales.
Hop 2: [PG](2024) → Tampax: Tampax remains under 'Feminine Care (Adult Incontinence, Menstrual Care)' in the same segment, maintaining its 24% share of net sales.

Hop 3: [PG](2022) → Tampax: Tampax was included in a broader 'Feminine Care' category that also included 'Feminine Care' and 'Adult Incontinence' under the Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment, which represented 25% of net sales.

questions.question: How did PepsiCo's references to its 4.000% Senior Note due 2047 evolve across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings, and what does this consistent disclosure pattern reveal about the note's role in the company's long-term capital structure strategy?
questions.answer: The 4.000% Senior Note due 2047 was consistently disclosed in all three years: in 2022 it referenced Exhibit 4.5 from the May 2, 2017 8-K filing; in 2023 it maintained the same May 2, 2017 reference; and in 2024 it continued to reference the identical Exhibit 4.5 from May 2, 2017. This consistent disclosure pattern across all three years with the exact same filing reference demonstrates that the 4.000% Senior Note due 2047 has remained a stable, long-term component of PepsiCo's capital structure since its issuance in 2017, with no modifications needed to its form or terms over this three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2022) → [4.000% Senior Note due 2047]: References Exhibit 4.5 from May 2, 2017 8-K filing in document chunk
Hop 2: [PEP](2023) → [4.000% Senior Note due 2047]: Also references Exhibit 4.5 from May 2, 2017 8-K filing in document chunk
Hop 3: [PEP](2024) → [4.000% Senior Note due 2047]: Continues to reference Exhibit 4.5 from May 2, 2017 8-K filing in document chunk

questions.question: How did PepsiCo's issuance terms and documentation of the 2.750% Senior Note due 2051 evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this multi-year filing pattern indicate about the company's long-term debt structuring strategy?
questions.answer: In 2022, the 2.750% Senior Note due 2051 was first introduced in a list of notes within a broader Board of Directors resolution (Exhibit 4.60), indicating initial authorization and planning. By 2023, the documentation had progressed to include a dedicated 'Form of 2.750% Senior Note due 2051' (Exhibit 4.51), suggesting that the instrument had moved from authorization to formal structuring and disclosure. In 2024, the note continued to be referenced with the same exhibit number (4.48), showing consistency in documentation and no material revision to the note's form. This progression reflects a deliberate, phased approach to long-term debt issuance, with early planning in 2022, formalization in 2023, and maintenance of structure in 2024, indicating stability in PepsiCo’s long-term capital strategy.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2022) → [2.750% Senior Note due 2051]: Introduced in a Board of Directors resolution (Exhibit 4.60) as part of a long list of notes, signaling initial authorization.
Hop 2: [PEP](2023) → [2.750% Senior Note due 2051]: Documented as a standalone 'Form of 2.750% Senior Note due 2051' (Exhibit 4.51), indicating formal structuring and disclosure.

Hop 3: [PEP](2024) → [2.750% Senior Note due 2051]: Repeatedly referenced as 'Form of 2.750% Senior Note due 2051' (Exhibit 4.48), showing no changes to the form, indicating consistency and finalization.

questions.question: How did PepsiCo's issuance and documentation of the 5.50% Senior Note due 2035 evolve across 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this multi-year filing pattern reveal about its long-term debt management strategy?
questions.answer: The 5.50% Senior Note due 2035 was consistently referenced across all three years, indicating ongoing documentation and potential refinancing or rollover activity. In 2022, it was listed as 'Form of 5.50% Senior Note due 2035, Series A' (Exhibit 4.31) referencing an 8-K filing from November 8, 2018. In 2023, the same note was referenced again (Exhibit 4.25) with the same filing history, showing continued acknowledgment of this debt instrument. In 2024, the note reappeared (Exhibit 4.23), again tied to the same 2018 filing. This repeated inclusion suggests that PepsiCo maintained this long-term debt obligation on its books without retiring or modifying it during the three-year period, signaling a stable, long-duration capital structure approach.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2022) → [5.50% Senior Note due 2035]: Listed as Exhibit 4.31, referencing a November 8, 2018 filing, indicating ongoing documentation of this long-term debt.
Hop 2: [PEP](2023) → [5.50% Senior Note due 2035]: Reappeared as Exhibit 4.25 with identical filing history, showing no change in the note’s status or structure.
Hop 3: [PEP](2024) → [5.50% Senior Note due 2035]: Listed again as Exhibit 4.23, maintaining the same reference to the 2018 filing, indicating no retirement or modification of the instrument.

questions.question: What does PepsiCo's consistent inclusion of the 3.000% Senior Note due 2027 across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 filings reveal about its medium-term debt financing strategy?
questions.answer: PepsiCo's consistent inclusion of the 3.000% Senior Note due 2027 across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 filings indicates a deliberate and stable approach to its medium-term debt financing. The note was first introduced in the 2022 filing (Exhibit 4.22), reaffirmed in the 2023 filing (Exhibit 4.19), and maintained in the 2024 filing (Exhibit 4.17). This consistency suggests that PepsiCo has preserved this instrument as a key component of its capital structure, signaling a strategic preference for stable, fixed-rate financing over variable instruments during a period of economic uncertainty and fluctuating interest rates.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2022) → [3.000% Senior Note due 2027]: Introduced in Exhibit 4.22 of the 2022 filing, indicating the note was part of PepsiCo’s active debt portfolio.
Hop 2: [PEP](2023) → [3.000% Senior Note due 2027]: Reaffirmed in Exhibit 4.19 of the 2023 filing, showing continued recognition and inclusion in the company's capital structure.
Hop 3: [PEP](2024) → [3.000% Senior Note due 2027]: Maintained in Exhibit 4.17 of the 2024 filing, demonstrating ongoing commitment to this fixed-rate debt instrument despite market volatility.

questions.question: How did PepsiCo's use of the 3.450% Senior Note due 2046 evolve across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings, and what does this pattern suggest about its long-term debt strategy?
questions.answer: The 3.450% Senior Note due 2046 was referenced in all three annual filings—2022, 2023, and 2024—indicating consistent inclusion in PepsiCo's long-term debt disclosures. In 2022, the note was listed among other senior notes as part of the company's broader debt structure, with its terms incorporated by reference to a 2016 filing. In 2023, the note appeared again in the exhibit list, maintaining its original description and again pointing to the October 6, 2016, Form 8-K filing for its terms. In 2024, the note remained in the exhibit list, continuing to reference the same 2016 filing for its form and terms. The consistent presence of this note across all three years suggests that PepsiCo has maintained this long-term debt instrument as a stable component of its capital structure without altering its terms or retiring the note. This reflects a strategy of relying on fixed long-term obligations to support financial stability and capital flexibility.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2022) → [3.450% Senior Note due 2046]: Listed in Exhibit 4.17, incorporated by reference to Exhibit 4.6 from the October 6, 2016, Form 8-K filing.
Hop 2: [PEP](2023) → [3.450% Senior Note due 2046]: Listed in Exhibit 4.16, again referencing Exhibit 4.6 from the October 6, 2016, Form 8-K filing for its form and terms.
Hop 3: [PEP](2024) → [3.450% Senior Note due 2046]: Listed in Exhibit 4.15, continuing to reference Exhibit 4.6 from the October 6, 2016, Form 8-K filing.
