## Table	of	Contents

## Regulation

Our	food	products	and	ingredients	are	subject	to	local,	national	and	multinational	regulations	related	to	labeling,	health and	nutrition	claims,	packaging,	pricing,	marketing	and	advertising,	and	related	areas.	In	addition,	various	jurisdictions regulate	our	operations	by	licensing	and	inspecting	our	manufacturing	plants	and	facilities,	enforcing	standards	for	select food	products,	grading	food	products,	and	regulating	trade	practices	related	to	the	sale	and	pricing	of	our	food	products. Many	of	the	food	commodities	we	use	in	our	operations	are	subject	to	government	agricultural	policy	and	intervention.	These policies	have	substantial	effects	on	prices	and	supplies	and	are	subject	to	periodic	governmental	and	administrative	review. In	addition,	increased	attention	to	environmental	and	social	issues	in	industry	supply	chains	has	led	to	developing	different types	of	regulation	in	many	countries.	The	lack	of	a	harmonized	approach	can	lead	to	uneven	scrutiny	or	enforcement,	which can	impact	our	operations.

Examples	of	laws	and	regulations	that	affect	our	business	include	workplace	safety	regulations;	selective	food	taxes;	data privacy;	labeling	requirements	such	as	front-of-pack	labeling	based	on	nutrient	profiles	or	environmental	claims;	sales	or media	 and	 marketing	 restrictions	 such	 as	 those	 on	 promotions	 or	 advertising	 products	 with	 specified	 nutrient	 profiles	 on certain	channels	or	platforms	or	during	certain	hours	of	the	day;	sanctions	on	sales	or	sourcing	of	raw	materials;	crossborder	trade	concessions	or	border	barriers;	corporate	tax	policies	of	the	United	States	and	other	countries;	and	packaging taxes.	 In	 addition,	 over	 25	 countries	 in	 the	 European	 Union	 have	 implemented	 extended	 producer	 responsibility	 ('EPR') policies	as	part	of	national	packaging	waste	policies	that	make	manufacturers	responsible	for	the	cost	of	recycling	food	and beverage	packaging	after	consumers	use	it.	These	range	from	mandatory	regulations	to	voluntary	agreements	between	government and	industry	to	voluntary	industry	initiatives.	EPR	policies	are	being	implemented	or	contemplated	in	other	jurisdictions around	the	world,	including	India,	Vietnam	and	certain	states	in	the	United	States.	Single-use	plastic	bans	and	other	plastic taxes	are	being	considered	in	Europe	as	well	as	countries	including	Indonesia	and	the	Philippines.

Throughout	the	countries	in	which	we	do	business,	we	are	subject	to	local,	national	and	multinational	environmental	laws	and regulations	 relating	 to	 the	 protection	 of	 the	 environment.	 We	 have	 programs	 across	 our	 business	 units	 designed	 to	 meet applicable	environmental	compliance	requirements.	In	the	United	States,	the	laws	and	regulations	include	the	Clean	Air	Act, the	Clean	Water	Act,	the	Resource	Conservation	and	Recovery	Act	and	the	Comprehensive	Environmental	Response,	Compensation, and	Liability	Act.	We	are	also	subject	to	legislation	designed	to	reduce	emissions	from	greenhouse	gases,	and	many	countries are	considering	introducing	carbon	taxes	that	could	increase	our	production	costs	or	those	of	our	suppliers.

We	continue	to	monitor	developments	in	laws	and	regulations.	Also	refer	to	Item	1A, Risk	Factors for	additional	information.

questions.question: How did MDLZ's allocation to buy-in annuity policies in its non-U.S. pension plans evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does this trend suggest about the company's liability management strategy for international pension obligations?
questions.answer: MDLZ's allocation to buy-in annuity policies in its non-U.S. pension plans decreased from 17% in 2022 to 16% in 2023, and was effectively discontinued by 2024, as the company shifted to fair value estimation methods for these instruments. This trend suggests a strategic move away from insurer-backed annuities toward more direct liability management and valuation control, aligning with broader pension de-risking or restructuring efforts.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MDLZ](2022) → [Buy-In Annuity Policies]: Allocated 17% to buy-in annuity policies in non-U.S. plans as of December 31, 2022.
Hop 2: [MDLZ](2023) → [Buy-In Annuity Policies]: Reduced allocation to 16% in non-U.S. plans as of December 31, 2023, indicating a slight de-emphasis.

Hop 3: [MDLZ](2024) → [Buy-In Annuity Policies]: No longer listed as a significant asset category; instead, fair value estimation methods were applied, suggesting discontinuation of buy-in annuity policies.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

## Fair value measurements

- Level 1 - includes primarily U.S and non-U.S. equity securities and gov ernment bonds v alued using quoted prices in activ e markets.
- Level 2 - includes primarily pooled funds, including assets in real estate pooled funds, v alued using net asset v alues of participation units held in common collective trusts, as reported by the managers of the trusts and as supported by the unit prices of actual purchase and sale transactions. Level 2 plan assets also include corporate bonds and other fixed-income securities, v alued using independent observ able market inputs, such as matrix pricing, yield curv es and indices.
- Level 3 - includes inv estments v alued using unobserv able inputs that reflect the plans' assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the assets, based on the best information av ailable.
- Fair  v alue  estimates  for  pooled  funds  are  calculated  by  the  inv estment  adv isor  when  reliable  quotations  or  pricing  serv ices  are  not  readily available for certain underlying securities. T he estimated v alue is based on either cost or last sale price for most of the securities v alued in this fashion.
- Fair v alue estimates for priv ate equity inv estments are calculated by the general partners using the market approach to estimate the fair v alue of priv ate  inv estments.  T he  market  approach  utilizes  prices  and  other  relev ant  information  generated  by  market  transactions,  type  of  security, degree of liquidity, restrictions on the disposition, latest round of financing data, company financial statements, relev ant v aluation multiples and discounted cash flow analyses.
- Fair v alue estimates for priv ate debt placements are calculated using standardized v aluation methods, including income-based techniques such as discounted cash flow projections or market-based techniques utilizing public and priv ate transaction multiples as comparables.
- Fair v alue estimates for real estate inv estments are calculated by inv estment managers using the present v alue of future cash flows expected to be receiv ed from the inv estments, based on v aluation methodologies such as appraisals, local market conditions, and current and projected operating performance.
- Fair v alue estimates for buy-in annuity policies (excluding the MDLZ  Global Plan buy-in) are calculated on a replacement policy v alue basis by discounting the projected cash flows of the plan members using a discount rate based on risk-free rates and adjustments for estimated lev els of insurer pricing. Fair v alue of the MDLZ Global Plan buy-in annuity is set equal to the estimated contract v alue as of December 31, 2024.
- Net asset v alue - primarily includes equity funds, fixed income funds, real estate funds, hedge funds and priv ate equity inv estments for which net asset v alues are normally used.

## Changes in our Lev el 3 plan assets included:

Net Realized

questions.question: How has MDLZ's disclosure around marketing and advertising regulations evolved from 2022 to 2024, particularly regarding data privacy, front-of-pack labeling, and extended producer responsibility (EPR) policies, and what does this progression suggest about the company's regulatory compliance focus?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, MDLZ's disclosures around marketing and advertising regulations have become more detailed and specific, particularly regarding data privacy, front-of-pack labeling, and EPR policies. In 2022, the company broadly referenced marketing and advertising regulations as part of a general regulatory framework, noting EPR policies in over 25 EU countries and their potential global expansion. By 2023, MDLZ explicitly included data privacy and front-of-pack labeling based on nutrient or environmental profiles as regulatory areas impacting marketing and advertising. In 2024, the company further reinforced its acknowledgment of these regulations, embedding them more deeply within its ESG governance structure and Board-level oversight, particularly under the Governance, Membership and Sustainability Committee. This progression suggests a growing strategic focus on regulatory compliance, especially around consumer data, product labeling transparency, and packaging waste responsibility, aligning with broader ESG goals and stakeholder expectations.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: MDLZ(2022) → Marketing and Advertising Regulations: Disclosed general regulatory environment including EPR policies in over 25 EU countries and potential global expansion in India, Vietnam, and U.S. states.

Hop 2: MDLZ(2023) → Marketing and Advertising Regulations: Expanded disclosure to include data privacy and front-of-pack labeling based on nutrient or environmental profiles as specific regulatory constraints on advertising.

Hop 3: MDLZ(2024) → Marketing and Advertising Regulations: Further embedded marketing-related regulations within ESG governance, with Board-level oversight and integration into strategic planning and risk management.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

We discuss our ESG goals and programs in detail in our annual Snacking Made Right ESG report available on our website. Under Snacking Made Right - Reporting and Disclosure , we also publish an ESG disclosure data sheet that outlines our alignment with the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board ('SASB') and Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures ('TCFD') reporting frameworks. We also provide our CDP Climate Change , Water Security and Forests annual disclosures.

We have been recognized for our ongoing economic, environmental and social contributions. Each year since we created Mondelēz International in 2012 we have been listed on the Dow Jones Sustainability Index ('DJSI') - World and North American Indices. The DJSI selects the top 10% of global companies and top 20% of North American companies based on an extensive review of financial and sustainability programs within each industry. We are at the 96th percentile of our industry according to the latest DJSI report issued in November 2021.

## Intellectual Property

Our intellectual property rights (including trademarks, patents, copyrights, registered designs, proprietary trade secrets, recipes, technology and know-how) are material to our business.

We own numerous trademarks and patents in many countries around the world. Depending on the country, trademarks remain valid for as long as they are in use or their registration status is maintained. Trademark registrations generally are renewable for fixed terms. We also have patents for a number of current and potential products. Our patents cover inventions ranging from packaging techniques to processes relating to specific products and to the products themselves. Our issued patents extend for varying periods according to the date of patent application filing or grant and the legal term of patents in the various countries where patent protection is obtained. The actual protection afforded by a patent, which can vary from country to country, depends upon the type of patent, the scope of its coverage as determined by the patent office or courts in the country, and the availability of legal remedies in the country. While our patent portfolio is material to our business, the loss of one patent or a group of related patents would not have a material adverse effect on our business.

From time to time, we grant third parties licenses to use one or more of our trademarks, patents and/or proprietary trade secrets in connection with the manufacture, sale or distribution of third-party products. Similarly, we sell some products under brands, patents and/or proprietary trade secrets we license from third parties. In our agreement with Kraft Foods Group, Inc. (which is now part of The Kraft Heinz Company), we each granted the other party various licenses to use certain of our and their respective intellectual property rights in named jurisdictions following the spin-off of our North American grocery business in 2012.

## Regulation

Our food products and ingredients are subject to local, national and multinational regulations related to labeling, health and nutrition claims, packaging, pricing, marketing and advertising, data privacy and related areas. In addition, various jurisdictions regulate our operations by licensing and inspecting our manufacturing plants and facilities, enforcing standards for select food products, grading food products, and regulating trade practices related to the sale and pricing of our food products. Many of the food commodities we use in our operations are subject to government agricultural policy and intervention. These policies have substantial effects on prices and supplies and are subject to periodic governmental and administrative review. In addition, increased attention to environmental and social issues in industry supply chains has led to developing different types of regulation in many countries. The lack of a harmonized approach can lead to uneven scrutiny or enforcement, which can impact our operations.

Examples of laws and regulations that affect our business include workplace safety regulations; selective food taxes; labeling requirements such as front-of-pack labeling based on nutrient profiles or environmental claims; sales or media and marketing restrictions such as those on promotions or advertising products with specified nutrient profiles on certain channels or platforms or during certain hours of the day; sanctions on sales or sourcing of raw materials; crossborder trade concessions or border barriers; corporate tax policies of the United States and other countries; and packaging taxes. In addition, over 25 countries in the European Union have implemented extended producer responsibility ('EPR') policies as part of national packaging waste policies that make manufacturers responsible for the cost of recycling food and beverage packaging after consumers use it. These range from mandatory regulations to voluntary agreements between government and industry to voluntary industry initiatives. EPR policies are being implemented or contemplated in other jurisdictions around the world, including India, Vietnam and certain states in the United States. Single-use plastic bans and other plastic taxes are being considered in Europe as well as countries including Indonesia and the Philippines.

## Table	of	Contents

## Regulation

Our	food	products	and	ingredients	are	subject	to	local,	national	and	multinational	regulations	related	to	labeling,	health and	nutrition	claims,	packaging,	pricing,	marketing	and	advertising,	and	related	areas.	In	addition,	various	jurisdictions regulate	our	operations	by	licensing	and	inspecting	our	manufacturing	plants	and	facilities,	enforcing	standards	for	select food	products,	grading	food	products,	and	regulating	trade	practices	related	to	the	sale	and	pricing	of	our	food	products. Many	of	the	food	commodities	we	use	in	our	operations	are	subject	to	government	agricultural	policy	and	intervention.	These policies	have	substantial	effects	on	prices	and	supplies	and	are	subject	to	periodic	governmental	and	administrative	review. In	addition,	increased	attention	to	environmental	and	social	issues	in	industry	supply	chains	has	led	to	developing	different types	of	regulation	in	many	countries.	The	lack	of	a	harmonized	approach	can	lead	to	uneven	scrutiny	or	enforcement,	which can	impact	our	operations.

Examples	of	laws	and	regulations	that	affect	our	business	include	workplace	safety	regulations;	selective	food	taxes;	data privacy;	labeling	requirements	such	as	front-of-pack	labeling	based	on	nutrient	profiles	or	environmental	claims;	sales	or media	 and	 marketing	 restrictions	 such	 as	 those	 on	 promotions	 or	 advertising	 products	 with	 specified	 nutrient	 profiles	 on certain	channels	or	platforms	or	during	certain	hours	of	the	day;	sanctions	on	sales	or	sourcing	of	raw	materials;	crossborder	trade	concessions	or	border	barriers;	corporate	tax	policies	of	the	United	States	and	other	countries;	and	packaging taxes.	 In	 addition,	 over	 25	 countries	 in	 the	 European	 Union	 have	 implemented	 extended	 producer	 responsibility	 ('EPR') policies	as	part	of	national	packaging	waste	policies	that	make	manufacturers	responsible	for	the	cost	of	recycling	food	and beverage	packaging	after	consumers	use	it.	These	range	from	mandatory	regulations	to	voluntary	agreements	between	government and	industry	to	voluntary	industry	initiatives.	EPR	policies	are	being	implemented	or	contemplated	in	other	jurisdictions around	the	world,	including	India,	Vietnam	and	certain	states	in	the	United	States.	Single-use	plastic	bans	and	other	plastic taxes	are	being	considered	in	Europe	as	well	as	countries	including	Indonesia	and	the	Philippines.

Throughout	the	countries	in	which	we	do	business,	we	are	subject	to	local,	national	and	multinational	environmental	laws	and regulations	 relating	 to	 the	 protection	 of	 the	 environment.	 We	 have	 programs	 across	 our	 business	 units	 designed	 to	 meet applicable	environmental	compliance	requirements.	In	the	United	States,	the	laws	and	regulations	include	the	Clean	Air	Act, the	Clean	Water	Act,	the	Resource	Conservation	and	Recovery	Act	and	the	Comprehensive	Environmental	Response,	Compensation, and	Liability	Act.	We	are	also	subject	to	legislation	designed	to	reduce	emissions	from	greenhouse	gases,	and	many	countries are	considering	introducing	carbon	taxes	that	could	increase	our	production	costs	or	those	of	our	suppliers.

We	continue	to	monitor	developments	in	laws	and	regulations.	Also	refer	to	Item	1A, Risk	Factors for	additional	information.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's disclosure and treatment of the 0.125% Notes due 2029 evolve across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings, and what does this reveal about the consistency of its debt instrument structuring over time?
questions.answer: The Coca-Cola Company's treatment of the 0.125% Notes due 2029 remained consistent across all three filings, with each year explicitly referencing the same Exhibit 4.4 from Form 8-K filings in September 2020 and March 2021. In 2022, the note was listed in Exhibit 4.23 and again in 4.31, each time citing the same underlying documentation. In 2023, it appeared in Exhibit 4.23 and again in 4.31, maintaining identical source references. In 2024, the note was again disclosed in Exhibit 4.23 and 4.31, with no change in the referenced Exhibit 4.4 filings. This reveals a consistent approach to structuring and disclosing this particular debt instrument over three consecutive reporting cycles, suggesting a stable capital market strategy for short-to-medium-term financing needs.

Hop 3: KO(2023) → 0.125% Notes due 2029: Disclosed in Exhibit 4.23 and again in 4.31, maintaining identical references to Exhibit 4.4 from the same 8-K filings as in previous years.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's issuance of notes with a 1.000% interest rate due in 2028 evolve across 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this pattern suggest about the company's debt strategy for that specific instrument?
questions.answer: The Coca-Cola Company consistently referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2028 in all three years—2022, 2023, and 2024—indicating ongoing acknowledgment and potential maintenance of this debt instrument. However, in 2024, the company introduced significantly higher-yielding notes (e.g., 5.000% Notes due 2034 and 5.300% Notes due 2054), suggesting a broader strategic shift toward issuing higher-interest debt, while maintaining visibility on the 1.000% Notes due 2028. This implies that while the 1.000% Notes due 2028 remained part of the company's long-term debt structure, KO pursued more aggressive borrowing terms in 2024, possibly to fund new initiatives or refinance existing obligations.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2022) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: The 1.000% Notes due 2028 were explicitly referenced in KO’s 2022 filings (Exhibit 4.26), indicating the note was active and documented.

Hop 2: KO(2023) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: In 2023, KO again referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2028 (Exhibit 4.26), showing continuity in the company's disclosure and likely ongoing liability management related to this instrument.

Hop 3: KO(2024) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: In 2024, KO once more included the 1.000% Notes due 2028 in its filings (Exhibit 4.26), maintaining consistency in disclosures. However, 2024 also introduced new, higher-interest notes (e.g., 5.000% Notes due 2034), signaling a shift in financing strategy.

questions.question: How did Coca-Cola's issuance of long-term debt instruments, particularly the 3.000% Notes due 2051, evolve across 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's capital structure strategy?
questions.answer: In 2022, Coca-Cola referenced the 3.000% Notes due 2051 in its 10-K filing (Exhibit 4.6 to the May 5, 2021 Form 8-K), indicating the instrument was part of a broader set of debt instruments with varying maturities and interest rates. In 2023, the company again included the 3.000% Notes due 2051 in its 10-K filing, maintaining the same exhibit reference, which shows continuity in its long-term debt portfolio. By 2024, Coca-Cola introduced new instruments with higher coupon rates, such as the 5.000% Notes due 2034 and the 5.300% Notes due 2054, while still retaining the 3.000% Notes due 2051 in its disclosures. This progression indicates that Coca-Cola maintained the 3.000% Notes due 2051 as a stable component of its capital structure while diversifying its debt portfolio with higher-yielding instruments, likely to balance long-term obligations with current market interest rate conditions.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2022) → 3.000% Notes due 2051: The 3.000% Notes due 2051 were referenced in Exhibit 4.6 to the May 5, 2021 Form 8-K, indicating the company had issued this long-term debt instrument as part of its broader capital structure.

Hop 2: KO(2023) → 3.000% Notes due 2051: The 3.000% Notes due 2051 were again referenced in the 2023 10-K filing under the same exhibit, showing continuity in the company's long-term debt offerings without modification.

Hop 3: KO(2024) → 3.000% Notes due 2051: In 2024, the 3.000% Notes due 2051 remained part of the company's disclosures, but were now accompanied by newer, higher-yielding instruments such as the 5.000% Notes due 2034 and 5.300% Notes due 2054, suggesting a strategic diversification of debt maturities and coupon structures.

questions.question: How did Coca-Cola's long-term debt instrument strategy evolve from 2022 through 2024, particularly in relation to the 1.000% Notes due 2041 and the introduction of higher-yielding notes in 2024?
questions.answer: Coca-Cola consistently referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2041 across all three years, first in 2022 (Exhibit 4.33), again in 2023 (Exhibit 4.33), and once more in 2024 (Exhibit 4.33). However, by 2024, the company introduced significantly higher-yielding debt instruments, including 5.000% Notes due 2034, 5.300% Notes due 2054, and 5.400% Notes due 2064. This marks a clear shift in financing strategy, as earlier years featured lower-yielding instruments like the 0.400% Notes due 2030 in 2022 and the 0.950% Notes due 2036 in 2023. The introduction of high-yield, long-duration notes in 2024 suggests a recalibration of the company's debt portfolio to align with changing market conditions.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2022) → 1.000% Notes due 2041: KO referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2041 and also issued lower-yielding instruments like the 0.400% Notes due 2030.
Hop 2: KO(2023) → 1.000% Notes due 2041: KO again referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2041 and highlighted the 0.950% Notes due 2036, maintaining a focus on low-yield instruments.

Hop 3: KO(2024) → 1.000% Notes due 2041: KO continued to reference the 1.000% Notes due 2041 but introduced significantly higher-yielding notes, including the 5.000% Notes due 2034, 5.300% Notes due 2054, and 5.400% Notes due 2064.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's use of estimates of sales proceeds in valuing nonpublicly traded investments evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year progression reveal about management's approach to fair value assessment in emerging markets?
questions.answer: In 2022, Coca-Cola disclosed the use of estimates of sales proceeds as part of its valuation methodology for nonpublicly traded investments, specifically citing an $87 million temporary impairment for Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings Inc. In 2023, the company reaffirmed its reliance on estimates of sales proceeds as a core valuation method for nonpublic investments, emphasizing sensitivity to emerging market cash flow predictability. By 2024, Coca-Cola continued to apply estimates of sales proceeds but placed greater emphasis on their role alongside discounted cash flows and appraisals, signaling a more structured and consistent application of valuation methodologies. This evolution shows a maturing and formalization of fair value assessment practices, particularly for investments in markets where cash flow forecasting is challenging.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [KO](2022) → [Estimates of Sales Proceeds]: Discloses use of estimates of sales proceeds as a valuation methodology for nonpublic investments, with specific reference to an $87 million temporary impairment for CCBJHI.
Hop 2: [KO](2023) → [Estimates of Sales Proceeds]: Reaffirms reliance on estimates of sales proceeds, highlighting sensitivity to cash flow predictability in emerging markets.
Hop 3: [KO](2024) → [Estimates of Sales Proceeds]: Continues using estimates of sales proceeds, now integrated more formally with discounted cash flows and appraisals for fair value assessments.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
Statements for the discussion of impairment charges. Refer to the heading 'Operations Review' below for additional information related to our present business environment.

As of December 31, 2021, the carrying value of our investment in Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings Inc. ('CCBJHI') exceeded its fair value by $87 million, or 18 percent. Based on the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than our carrying value and our intent and ability to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in market value, management determined that the decline in fair value was temporary in nature. Therefore, we did not record an impairment charge related to the investment.

Our equity method investees also perform such recoverability and impairment tests. If an impairment charge is recorded by one of our equity method investees, the Company records its proportionate share of such charge as a reduction of equity income (loss) net in our consolidated statement of income. However, the actual amount we record with respect to our proportionate share of such charge may be impacted by items such as basis differences, deferred taxes and deferred gains.

## Investments in Equity and Debt Securities

We measure all equity investments that do not result in consolidation and are not accounted for under the equity method at fair value with the change in fair value included in net income. We use quoted market prices to determine the fair value of equity securities with readily determinable fair values. For equity securities without readily determinable fair values, we have elected the measurement alternative under which we measure these investments at cost minus impairment, if any, plus or minus changes resulting from observable price changes in orderly transactions for the identical or a similar investment of the same issuer. Management assesses each of these investments on an individual basis.

Our investments in debt securities are carried at either amortized cost or fair value. The cost basis is determined by the specific identification method. Investments in debt securities that the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are carried at amortized cost and classified as held-to-maturity. Investments in debt securities that are not classified as held-to-maturity are carried at fair value and classified as either trading or available-for-sale. Realized and unrealized gains and losses on trading debt securities as well as realized gains and losses on available-for-sale debt securities are included in net income. Unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, on available-for-sale debt securities are included in our consolidated balance sheet as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss), except for the changes in fair values attributable to the currency risk being hedged, if applicable, which are included in net income.

Equity securities with readily determinable fair values that are not accounted for under the equity method and debt securities classified as trading are not assessed for impairment, since they are carried at fair value with the change in fair value included in net income. Equity method investments, equity securities without readily determinable fair values and debt securities classified as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity are reviewed each reporting period to determine whether a significant event or change in circumstances has occurred that may have an adverse effect on the fair value of each investment. When such events or changes occur, we evaluate the fair value compared to our cost basis in the investment. We also perform this evaluation every reporting period for each investment for which our cost basis has exceeded the fair value. The fair values of most of our Company's investments in publicly traded companies are often readily available based on quoted market prices. For investments in nonpublicly traded companies, management's assessment of fair value is based on valuation methodologies including discounted cash flows, estimates of sales proceeds and appraisals, as appropriate. We consider the assumptions that we believe a market participant would use in evaluating estimated future cash flows when employing the discounted cash flow or estimates of sales proceeds valuation methodologies. The ability to accurately predict future cash flows, especially in emerging and developing markets, may impact the determination of fair value. In the event the fair value of an investment declines below our cost basis, management is required to determine if the decline in fair value is other than temporary. If management determines the decline is other than temporary, an impairment charge is recorded. Management's assessment as to the nature of a decline in fair value is based on, among other things, the length of time and the extent to which the market value has been less than our cost basis; the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer; and our intent and ability to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in market value.

## Property, Plant and Equipment

Certain events or changes in circumstances may indicate that the recoverability of the carrying amount or remaining useful life of property, plant and equipment should be assessed, including, among others, the manner or length of time in which the Company intends to use the asset, a significant decrease in market value, a significant change in the business climate in a particular market, or a current period operating or cash flow loss combined with historical losses and/or projected future losses. When such events or changes in circumstances are present and a recoverability test is performed, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset or asset group and its eventual disposition. These estimated future cash flows are consistent with those we use in our internal planning. If the sum of the expected future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges) is less than the carrying amount, we recognize an impairment charge. The impairment charge

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's issuance of 1.000% Notes due 2028 evolve across 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern reveal about the company's short-to-intermediate term debt financing strategy?
questions.answer: The Coca-Cola Company consistently referenced the 1.000% Notes due 2028 in its filings across 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating ongoing reliance on this instrument as part of its broader debt financing strategy. In 2022 and 2023, the Notes due 2028 were listed among other debt instruments, showing continuity in referencing the September 18, 2020 filing as the source document. In 2024, while the 1.000% Notes due 2028 remained referenced, KO introduced a new set of higher-yielding notes (e.g., 5.000% Notes due 2034 and 5.300% Notes due 2054), suggesting a strategic shift toward issuing higher-yield debt instruments for longer-term financing needs. This evolution indicates a dual approach: maintaining existing lower-yield instruments for near-term obligations while leveraging rising interest environments for long-term capital.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(2023) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: The Notes due 2028 were referenced in Exhibit 4.26, incorporated from the September 18, 2020 Form 8-K filing, showing continued inclusion in the company's capital structure.

Hop 2: KO(2024) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: The Notes due 2028 were again referenced in Exhibit 4.26, maintaining their place in KO’s debt portfolio, but new high-yield notes (e.g., 5.000% Notes due 2034 and 5.300% Notes due 2054) were introduced, indicating a broader financing strategy.

Hop 3: KO(2022) → 1.000% Notes due 2028: The Notes due 2028 were referenced in Exhibit 4.26, similarly incorporated from the September 18, 2020 filing, showing consistent documentation and no new issuance activity in that year.

questions.question: How did The Coca-Cola Company's reliance on estimates of sales proceeds for valuing nonpublic equity investments evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this reveal about management's confidence in predicting recovery in markets like Japan where the carrying value exceeded fair value by $87 million in 2022?
questions.answer: From 2022 through 2024, The Coca-Cola Company consistently used estimates of sales proceeds as part of its valuation methodology for nonpublic equity investments, but the context and implications of these estimates evolved. In 2022, the company disclosed that the carrying value of its investment in Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings Inc. exceeded its fair value by $87 million, or 18%, yet management deemed the decline temporary, indicating confidence in eventual recovery. In 2023 and 2024, the disclosures reiterated the use of estimates of sales proceeds as a valuation methodology but placed increasing emphasis on the assumptions a market participant would use in evaluating future cash flows, particularly in emerging and developing markets. This evolution suggests that while the company maintained its valuation methodology, it became more attuned to external market perspectives and macroeconomic risks, especially in regions where fair value predictions are more volatile.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [KO](2023) → [Estimates of Sales Proceeds]: In 2023, KO reiterated its use of estimates of sales proceeds as part of the valuation methodology for nonpublic equity investments, emphasizing alignment with market participant assumptions in evaluating future cash flows.

Hop 2: [KO](2024) → [Estimates of Sales Proceeds]: In 2024, KO maintained the same valuation methodology but increased focus on the importance of market participant assumptions, especially in emerging markets, suggesting a more cautious approach to predicting fair value.

Hop 3: [KO](2022) → [Estimates of Sales Proceeds]: In 2022, KO disclosed a significant $87 million (18%) overvaluation of its investment in Japan, yet management judged the decline as temporary, showing strong confidence in recovery and the predictive power of its estimates of sales proceeds.

## NOTE	4:	INVESTMENTS

We	measure	all	equity	investments	that	do	not	result	in	consolidation	and	are	not	accounted	for	under	the	equity	method	at fair	value	with	the	change	in	fair	value	included	in	net	income.	We	use	quoted	market	prices	to	determine	the	fair	values	of equity	securities	with	readily	determinable	fair	values.	For	equity	securities	without	readily	determinable	fair	values,	we have	elected	the	measurement	alternative	under	which	we	measure	these	investments	at	cost	minus	impairment,	if	any,	plus	or minus	changes	resulting	from	observable	price	changes	in	orderly	transactions	for	the	identical	or	a	similar	investment	of the	same	issuer.	Management	assesses	each	of	these	investments	on	an	individual	basis.

Our	investments	in	debt	securities	are	carried	at	either	amortized	cost	or	fair	value.	The	cost	basis	is	determined	by	the specific	identification	method.	Investments	in	debt	securities	that	the	Company	has	the	positive	intent	and	ability	to	hold to	maturity	are	carried	at	amortized	cost	and	classified	as	held-to-maturity.	Investments	in	debt	securities	that	are	not classified	as	held-to-maturity	are	carried	at	fair	value	and	classified	as	either	trading	or	available-for-sale.	Realized	and unrealized	gains	and	losses	on	trading	debt	securities	as	well	as	realized	gains	and	losses	on	available-for-sale	debt securities	are	included	in	net	income.	Unrealized	gains	and	losses,	net	of	tax,	on	available-for-sale	debt	securities	are included	in	our	consolidated	balance	sheet	as	a	component	of	AOCI,	except	for	the	changes	in	fair	values	attributable	to	the currency	risk	being	hedged,	if	applicable,	which	are	included	in	net	income.	Refer	to	Note	5	for	additional	information related	to	the	Company's	fair	value	hedges	of	available-for-sale	debt	securities.

Equity	securities	with	readily	determinable	fair	values	that	are	not	accounted	for	under	the	equity	method	and	debt securities	classified	as	trading	are	not	assessed	for	impairment,	since	they	are	carried	at	fair	value	with	the	change	in fair	value	included	in	net	income.	Equity	method	investments,	equity	securities	without	readily	determinable	fair	values	and debt	securities	classified	as	available-for-sale	or	held-to-maturity	are	reviewed	each	reporting	period	to	determine	whether a	significant	event	or	change	in	circumstances	has	occurred	that	may	have	an	adverse	effect	on	the	fair	value	of	each investment.	When	such	events	or	changes	occur,	we	evaluate	the	fair	value	compared	to	our	cost	basis	in	the	investment.	We also	perform	this	evaluation	every	reporting	period	for	each	investment	for	which	our	cost	basis	has	exceeded	the	fair	value. The	fair	values	of	most	of	our	Company's	investments	in	publicly	traded	companies	are	readily	available	based	on	quoted market	prices.	For	investments	in	nonpublicly	traded	companies,	management's	assessment	of	fair	value	is	based	on	various valuation	methodologies,	including	discounted	cash	flows,	estimates	of	sales	proceeds,	and	appraisals,	as	appropriate.	We consider	the	assumptions	that	we	believe	a	market	participant	would	use	in	evaluating	estimated	future	cash	flows	when employing	the	discounted	cash	flow	or	estimates	of	sales	proceeds	valuation	methodologies.	The	ability	to	accurately	predict future	cash	flows,	especially	in	emerging	and	developing	markets,	may	impact	the	determination	of	fair	value.	In	the	event the	fair	value	of	an	investment	declines	below	our	cost	basis,	management	is	required	to	determine	if	the	decline	in	fair value	is	other	than	temporary.	If	management	determines	the	decline	is	other	than	temporary,	an	impairment	charge	is recorded.	Management's	assessment	as	to	the	nature	of	a	decline	in	fair	value	is	based	on,	among	other	things,	the	length	of time	and	the	extent	to	which	the	market	value	has	been	less	than	our	cost	basis;	the	financial	condition	and	near-term prospects	of	the	issuer;	and	our	intent	and	ability	to	retain	the	investment	for	a	period	of	time	sufficient	to	allow	for	any anticipated	recovery	in	market	value.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## NOTE 4: INVESTMENTS

We measure all equity investments that do not result in consolidation and are not accounted for under the equity method at fair value, with the change in fair value included in net income. We use quoted market prices to determine the fair values of equity securities with readily determinable fair values. For equity securities without readily determinable fair values, we have elected the measurement alternative under which we measure these investments at cost minus impairment, if any, plus or minus changes resulting from observable price changes in orderly transactions for the identical or a similar investment of the same issuer. Management assesses each of these investments on an individual basis.

Our investments in debt securities are carried at either amortized cost or fair value. The cost basis is determined by the specific identification method. Investments in debt securities that the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are carried at amortized cost and classified as held-to-maturity. Investments in debt securities that are not classified as held-to-maturity are carried at fair value and classified as either trading or available-for-sale. Realized and unrealized gains and losses on trading debt securities as well as realized gains and losses on available-for-sale debt securities are included in net income. Unrealized gains and losses, net of tax , on available-for-sale debt securities are included in our consolidated balance sheet as a component of AOCI, except for the changes in fair values attributable to the currency risk being hedged, if applicable, which are included in net income. Refer to Note 5 for additional information related to the Company's fair value hedges of available-for-sale debt securities.

Equity securities with readily determinable fair values that are not accounted for under the equity method and debt securities classified as trading are not assessed for impairment, since they are carried at fair value with the change in fair value included in net income. Equity method investments, equity securities without readily determinable fair values and debt securities classified as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity are reviewed each reporting period to determine whether a significant event or change in circumstances has occurred that may have an adverse effect on the fair value of each investment. When such events or changes occur, we evaluate the fair value compared to our cost basis in the investment. We also perform this evaluation every reporting period for each investment for which our cost basis has exceeded the fair value. The fair values of most of our Company's investments in publicly traded companies are readily available based on quoted market prices. For investments in nonpublicly traded companies, management's assessment of fair value is based on various valuation methodologies, including discounted cash flows, estimates of sales proceeds, and appraisals, as appropriate. We consider the assumptions that we believe a market participant would use in evaluating estimated future cash flows when employing the discounted cash flow or estimates of sales proceeds valuation methodologies. The ability to accurately predict future cash flows, especially in emerging and developing markets, may impact the determination of fair value. In the event the fair value of an investment declines below our cost basis, management is required to determine if the decline in fair value is other than temporary. If management determines the decline is other than temporary, an impairment charge is recorded. Management's assessment as to the nature of a decline in fair value is based on, among other things, the length of time and the extent to which the market value has been less than our cost basis; the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer; and our intent and ability to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in market value.

## Equity Securities

The carrying values of our equity securities were included in the following line items in our consolidated balance sheets (in millions):

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
Statements for the discussion of impairment charges. Refer to the heading 'Operations Review' below for additional information related to our present business environment.

As of December 31, 2021, the carrying value of our investment in Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings Inc. ('CCBJHI') exceeded its fair value by $87 million, or 18 percent. Based on the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than our carrying value and our intent and ability to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in market value, management determined that the decline in fair value was temporary in nature. Therefore, we did not record an impairment charge related to the investment.

Our equity method investees also perform such recoverability and impairment tests. If an impairment charge is recorded by one of our equity method investees, the Company records its proportionate share of such charge as a reduction of equity income (loss) net in our consolidated statement of income. However, the actual amount we record with respect to our proportionate share of such charge may be impacted by items such as basis differences, deferred taxes and deferred gains.

## Investments in Equity and Debt Securities

We measure all equity investments that do not result in consolidation and are not accounted for under the equity method at fair value with the change in fair value included in net income. We use quoted market prices to determine the fair value of equity securities with readily determinable fair values. For equity securities without readily determinable fair values, we have elected the measurement alternative under which we measure these investments at cost minus impairment, if any, plus or minus changes resulting from observable price changes in orderly transactions for the identical or a similar investment of the same issuer. Management assesses each of these investments on an individual basis.

Our investments in debt securities are carried at either amortized cost or fair value. The cost basis is determined by the specific identification method. Investments in debt securities that the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are carried at amortized cost and classified as held-to-maturity. Investments in debt securities that are not classified as held-to-maturity are carried at fair value and classified as either trading or available-for-sale. Realized and unrealized gains and losses on trading debt securities as well as realized gains and losses on available-for-sale debt securities are included in net income. Unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, on available-for-sale debt securities are included in our consolidated balance sheet as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss), except for the changes in fair values attributable to the currency risk being hedged, if applicable, which are included in net income.

Equity securities with readily determinable fair values that are not accounted for under the equity method and debt securities classified as trading are not assessed for impairment, since they are carried at fair value with the change in fair value included in net income. Equity method investments, equity securities without readily determinable fair values and debt securities classified as available-for-sale or held-to-maturity are reviewed each reporting period to determine whether a significant event or change in circumstances has occurred that may have an adverse effect on the fair value of each investment. When such events or changes occur, we evaluate the fair value compared to our cost basis in the investment. We also perform this evaluation every reporting period for each investment for which our cost basis has exceeded the fair value. The fair values of most of our Company's investments in publicly traded companies are often readily available based on quoted market prices. For investments in nonpublicly traded companies, management's assessment of fair value is based on valuation methodologies including discounted cash flows, estimates of sales proceeds and appraisals, as appropriate. We consider the assumptions that we believe a market participant would use in evaluating estimated future cash flows when employing the discounted cash flow or estimates of sales proceeds valuation methodologies. The ability to accurately predict future cash flows, especially in emerging and developing markets, may impact the determination of fair value. In the event the fair value of an investment declines below our cost basis, management is required to determine if the decline in fair value is other than temporary. If management determines the decline is other than temporary, an impairment charge is recorded. Management's assessment as to the nature of a decline in fair value is based on, among other things, the length of time and the extent to which the market value has been less than our cost basis; the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer; and our intent and ability to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in market value.

## Property, Plant and Equipment

Certain events or changes in circumstances may indicate that the recoverability of the carrying amount or remaining useful life of property, plant and equipment should be assessed, including, among others, the manner or length of time in which the Company intends to use the asset, a significant decrease in market value, a significant change in the business climate in a particular market, or a current period operating or cash flow loss combined with historical losses and/or projected future losses. When such events or changes in circumstances are present and a recoverability test is performed, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset or asset group and its eventual disposition. These estimated future cash flows are consistent with those we use in our internal planning. If the sum of the expected future cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges) is less than the carrying amount, we recognize an impairment charge. The impairment charge

questions.question: What does the consistent disclosure of PepsiCo's 4.000% Senior Note due 2047 across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings suggest about the company's long-term debt strategy, and how does this compare to its treatment of shorter-dated instruments like the 2.150% Senior Note due 2024 and the 0.750% Senior Note due 2027?
questions.answer: The consistent disclosure of the 4.000% Senior Note due 2047 across all three filings (2022, 2023, and 2024) indicates that PepsiCo maintains a long-term liability management strategy focused on stable, extended-duration financing. This contrasts with the company's treatment of shorter-dated notes, such as the 2.150% Senior Note due 2024 (referenced in 2023) and the 0.750% Senior Note due 2027 (introduced in 2024), which appear in only one or two filings and likely reflect more time-sensitive capital needs or refinancing activities. The 2022 filing also included a 2.500% Senior Note due 2022, which had matured by 2023, further highlighting the dynamic nature of short-term debt versus the persistent presence of long-term obligations like the 2047 note. This pattern suggests PepsiCo is leveraging long-term debt to secure capital at fixed rates, reducing refinancing risk and supporting financial stability over decades.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2023) → [4.000% Senior Note due 2047]: Explicitly listed in the 2023 10-K filing, indicating continued relevance in PepsiCo’s long-term debt portfolio.
Hop 2: [PEP](2024) → [4.000% Senior Note due 2047]: Reappears in the 2024 10-K, confirming the ongoing inclusion of this long-term obligation in the company's capital structure.

Hop 3: [PEP](2022) → [4.000% Senior Note due 2047]: Present in the 2022 10-K filing, showing that this debt instrument has been consistently disclosed for at least three consecutive reporting periods.

questions.question: What does PepsiCo's treatment of its 2.750% Senior Note due 2051 across 2022–2024 filings reveal about its long-term debt strategy in a rising interest rate environment?
questions.answer: PepsiCo's treatment of the 2.750% Senior Note due 2051 across 2022–2024 filings shows a consistent approach to long-term debt management, despite rising interest rates. In 2022, the note was listed among various other senior notes in the exhibit index, indicating it was part of a broader capital structure (PEP_10k_2022.pdf:page_135:chunk_1). In 2023, the note was explicitly called out in the exhibit index with a reference to the 2021 Form 8-K filing, suggesting it remained an active part of PepsiCo’s long-term financing plans (PEP_10k_2023.pdf:page_128:chunk_2). In 2024, the note was again referenced in the same format and position as in 2023, showing no changes to its treatment even as newer, higher-yielding notes (e.g., 5.250% Senior Note due 2054) were introduced (PEP_10k_2024.pdf:page_129:chunk_2). This consistency suggests that PepsiCo maintained a stable long-term capital strategy, preserving access to long-dated, fixed-rate debt even as short-term borrowing costs rose.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PEP(2023) → 2.750% Senior Note due 2051: Explicitly referenced in Exhibit 4.3 to the 2021 Form 8-K, showing it was still being tracked and disclosed as part of the company's debt structure.
Hop 2: PEP(2024) → 2.750% Senior Note due 2051: Continued to be listed in the same format and position as in 2023, indicating no revision or removal despite new long-term debt issuances.
Hop 3: PEP(2022) → 2.750% Senior Note due 2051: Listed among a wide range of other senior notes, signaling that it was already integrated into the capital structure as a long-term liability.

questions.question: How did PepsiCo's use of the 5.50% Senior Note due 2035 evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this consistent inclusion reveal about its long-term debt financing strategy relative to other instruments?
questions.answer: PepsiCo consistently referenced the 5.50% Senior Note due 2035 across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 10-K filings, demonstrating a strategic emphasis on this instrument as part of its long-term capital structure. In 2022 (Exhibit 4.35), 2023 (Exhibit 4.29), and 2024 (Exhibit 4.27), the note was linked to the same Registration Statement on Form S-4 (No. 333-228466) filed on November 19, 2018, indicating it was a core, unchanging component of its debt portfolio. The persistence of this note, alongside the introduction of newer, lower-yield instruments like the 0.750% Senior Note due 2027 (2024) and the 1.125% Senior Note due 2031 (2024), suggests a dual approach: maintaining stable, higher-yielding long-term obligations while also leveraging favorable interest environments for newer, cheaper debt. This indicates a balanced capital management strategy focused on both reliability and flexibility.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2023) → [5.50% Senior Note due 2035]: 2023 filing includes the 5.50% Senior Note due 2035 (Exhibit 4.29), incorporated via the same 2018 registration statement.

Hop 2: [PEP](2024) → [5.50% Senior Note due 2035]: 2024 filing again references the same 5.50% Senior Note due 2035 (Exhibit 4.27) under the same registration statement, while also introducing newer low-yield notes.

Hop 3: [PEP](2022) → [5.50% Senior Note due 2035]: 2022 filing includes the 5.50% Senior Note due 2035 (Exhibit 4.35), showing the instrument was consistently maintained in disclosures over multiple years.

questions.question: How did PepsiCo's inclusion and characterization of the 3.000% Senior Note due 2027 evolve across its 2022, 2023, and 2024 annual filings, and what does this reveal about the company's long-term debt strategy?
questions.answer: The 3.000% Senior Note due 2027 was consistently included in PepsiCo's annual filings across 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating its ongoing significance in the company's capital structure. In 2022 (Exhibit 4.22), the note was listed among other senior notes, including the 2.150% Senior Note due 2024 and the 2.250% Senior Note due 2022, suggesting it was part of a broader set of medium-term financing instruments. In 2023 (Exhibit 4.19), the note was again included, this time alongside longer-dated instruments such as the 4.450% Senior Note due 2046 and the 3.450% Senior Note due 2046, indicating its role in a diversified debt maturity profile. In 2024 (Exhibit 4.17), the note continued to be referenced, now in the context of a filing that also included newer short-term notes like the 0.750% Senior Note due 2027 and the 1.125% Senior Note due 2031, suggesting a strategy of layering debt maturities to manage refinancing risk. While the interest rate and maturity date remained constant, the evolving context in which the 3.000% Senior Note due 2027 was presented indicates a consistent yet adaptive debt strategy that maintains certain fixed-rate liabilities while introducing newer, often lower-rate instruments to reflect market conditions.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PEP(2023) → 3.000% Senior Note due 2027: The note was included in Exhibit 4.19, filed October 10, 2017, and referenced in the 2023 filing as part of a broader set of long-term debt instruments.

Hop 2: PEP(2024) → 3.000% Senior Note due 2027: The note was referenced in Exhibit 4.17, filed October 10, 2017, and included in a filing that also introduced newer, lower-rate notes such as the 0.750% Senior Note due 2027.
Hop 3: PEP(2022) → 3.000% Senior Note due 2027: The note was listed in Exhibit 4.22, filed October 10, 2017, and presented alongside other mid-term notes like the 2.150% Senior Note due 2024.

questions.question: How did PepsiCo's disclosures regarding its 3.450% Senior Note due 2046 evolve across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this multi-year pattern suggest about the company's long-term debt structure and refinancing strategy?
questions.answer: PepsiCo consistently referenced the 3.450% Senior Note due 2046 in its filings across 2022, 2023, and 2024, indicating its ongoing presence in the company's long-term debt portfolio. In 2022, the note was listed as part of the company's broader debt instruments incorporated by reference to an October 6, 2016, filing. In 2023 and 2024, the note continued to appear in the same context, suggesting no material changes in its structure or status over the three-year period. This consistency implies that PepsiCo maintained this long-term obligation without amendment or refinancing during the observed timeframe, reflecting a stable approach to long-term capital structure.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PEP](2023) → [3.450% Senior Note due 2046]: Listed in 2023 as incorporated by reference to Exhibit 4.6 from an October 6, 2016, 8-K filing.
Hop 2: [PEP](2024) → [3.450% Senior Note due 2046]: Repeated in 2024 with identical reference to the October 6, 2016, filing, showing no structural change.
Hop 3: [PEP](2022) → [3.450% Senior Note due 2046]: Disclosed in 2022 with the same Exhibit 4.6 reference, confirming continuity in the note’s inclusion in disclosures.
